div.p: Trick for Trick: OR, The Debauch'd Hypocrite.
A COMEDY, As it is ACTED at the Theatre-Royal, By His MAJESTIE'S Servants.
LONDON, Printed for Langley Curtiss, in Goat-Court upon Ludgate-Hill, 1678.

div.head: PROLOGUE,
div.stage: Spoken by Mr. Haines in a Red Coat like a Common Souldier.
div.l: SInce there's a Dearth of Witt, and that to Play,
Is hardly worth one poor Brown George a Day;
I from the Poet, and our Friends within,
Am sent t'intreat, and your last Favours win,
E're we go hence and shall no more be seen.
For my part,—
I'le to the French Campaigne, where one may get
A certain Wholsome though a Homely Treat;
Good Oyl and Cooling Sallads, though no meat:
Good Campany, good honest Lowste Currs.
There's Honour to be got too— Honour, Sirs;
Honour that makes the General's Voice sound loud,
And serves instead of Brandy to the Crowd.
My Spirits are reviv'd; Methinks I hear
A Crew of Fire-fac'd Rogues embattled there,
Whose Motly Noses carry Hope and Fear:
Cry out, Fall on, we shall be Kings, Great Men,
Nay Emperours, the Devil knowes how, and when.
Then Shouting all, advance they to the Siege,
And to the Plunder fall with Priviledge.
Pray tell me then, is it not better farr,
To live abroad when other Nations Iarr,
Then 'mongst our selves to make a Civil Warr?
Are not these Bandaliers, this Sword, this Coat,
Better than Tipstaves, or a Baily's Note?
To day we Play Great Kings, strutt, bounce and fly,
But e're next Morn the Shop's shut up— God buy.
This by your great Unkindness is our Lott,
We share and share, 'tis true— but nothing's got.
Like lab'ring Bees we toyle for Witt, though poor,
Which you like Drones suck up, and hum for more,
But bring in nothing to the Winter-Store.
Witt is forgot; for with you Men of Miss,
Sence is unnatural as Marriage is—
Knowledge of this has made me what you see,
And if your tempers change not instantly,
Comedian Haines a man of Sword shall be.
'Tis true, my Loyalty is not preserv'd,
But that in many has for Profit swerv'd;
Besides, 'tis better to be hang'd than starv'd.

div.head: Trick for Trick: OR, The Debauch'd Hypocrite.
ACT I. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: COme prithee leave this Melancholick humour, Franck; Don't disguise thy temper: For if it be Love that causes it, as I shrewdly guess it is— thou dost so richly deserve to be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I am not of your mind, Sir, but I wish you'd tell me why.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, suppose it be for a Beautiful Woman— a smiling Rosie Charming melting Woman; one that kisses with Art, but uses none— that often sighs to add more grace to her speech; and speaks never, but to show the perfection of her Mind; that Sings with Skill, and Prayes with Zeal; And never Jilts a Man but to prove her own Innocency. In fine, One that is indeed the Jewel among Women. Do'st thou not know, O Man, O Mortal, dost thou not perceive that she has all this onely for Men— showes all her Beauties onely to please Men— ha! do'st thou not know this?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Not I 'faith; but I find my self very willing to be Instructed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well said, and 'faith thou sha't be instructed to some purpose before I leave thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: But prithee how shall I know when a Woman loves me, that does, and won't tell it me? my greatest Ignorance lyes in that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh— well remembred 'faith— why Franck— if she loves thee, when thou art in company with her, thou sha't see her leer upon thee— like a crafty Shop-keeper after a fellow that has bid him money.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Hylas is below, and come to visit ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hylas? Is he return'd to England so soon? Well, desire him to walk up.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Hylas! I believe I know him— if it be he I mean, he's a shallow fellow, much pleas'd with his own Inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You have hit him, Sir— he now were a fitter Person to give thee a Lecture about Women than I; he has been the most Inconstant, and the most adventurous Fool in the Town, been abus'd by all sorts of Women— and yet dares love a fresh.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: A very modish Character.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I believe Mad Tom's come back with him, Monsieur Thomas as we call him here, for they two have ever yet been Inseparable; but here he comes.

div.p: Ah Iack! welcome home 'faith— I am glad to see thee with all my heart; how do'st thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: 'Faith, very well, the better to see my dear Val in so good a humour— well, and prithee how fare all our Friends, and among the rest, all the Bona Roba's of the Age, ha? Any new faces of late worth a mans observance? Come, I know thou art generally acquainted, and thou art sure thou can'st not oblige me more, than by such a relation, what say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why only this, That to thy boundless comfort, the Town's full of e'm; But, for my part, thou know'st I want the faculty of Address— I am no Womans Man, Iack.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: How? no Womans Man— ye lie Val. d'ee hear? (and give me thy hand) I cannot oblige thee more than to tell thee so: But heark ye, is not that Frank Wellbred, there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The same; one that I can assure you, will be proud to be listed among your Friends.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Will he? and 'faith— I'll do him that honour instantly. Franck, thy humble Servant,— 'faith— I hardly knew thee at first— why sure, thou art plaguily alter'd, or else I am: Thou look'st quite another Man, than thou wert formerly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sir— Time blots the nearest Friends out of our Memories, And that's the reason that makes you think I am alter'd: But, though I am so, I see you hold your old humour still, You are the same. That is, as much a fool as ever. Aside.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p:
'Faith thou art in the right, I am so, I am as mad an Inconstant Debauch'd Son of a Whore as ever I was. Why what a Pox shou'd a
man do poreing, and dreaming out his time for, when he can spend it to better advantage, I am for a short life, and a merry, I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Faith, I believe thee, thou art a Latitudinarian in Debauchery; and for Hectring, Bilking, Drinking, and for Wenching, let thee alone.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ah Rogue, for Wenching let me alone, as thou say'st; For, if any Female scapes me, she must be a copy of my Grandame Eve; for from Fifteen to Five and fifty, I have try'd already.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Why, well said— what an impudent damn'd lying Rogue is this? Aside.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: But now we are talking of Debauchees— Prithee Val, Who do'st thou think is come over with me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, it may be, he that went with thee, the Bully of Covent-Garden, Mad Tom of Covent-Garden.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Why, what a Plaguy guess hast thou?— 'faith, thou art in the right, Mad Tom, Mounsieur Thomas is return'd, 'gad I believe thou art a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, no, I have only a small Familiar— well— I hope he has brought the same Virtues home with him, that he carried out?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ah, more, Val, more— he was but a Puny before he went, But now he's grown Arts Master— 'tis strange he has not been here; told me the first thing he did, shou'd be to Visit thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have not seen him yet, but I hear he has a Father in Town, I suppose, duty carries him thither first.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: He has so; why do'st thou not know him? Sir Wilding Frollick his own Father to a hair; didst thou never hear his Character?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No; prithee, what is't?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: 'Faith, a pleasant one— why Sir, the Old Knight is three times more debauch't than he, encourages him in it, and provides him Tutors, to teach him the Arts of Playing, Drinking, and Wenching, sent him to Travel, to learn Experience, he had like to have dis inherited him t'other day, for breaking his assignation with— an Old Whore, that was rotten seven years before, and was then under the Surgeon's hands; ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: A very hopeful Family.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: By St. Christopher, rare Creatures! ah! ye little fleering Quean you— Pox on her, what an Eye she has.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p:
Brother, pray let me desire you to receive my Cousin, Sir Peregrine Goodall's Daughter, a worthy person, and one that is pleas'd to
give me the honour of her Love, and Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She shall command here as my self— Madam, your humble Servant. Salutes her.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I must have a touch too— fair Saint your most— devoted— ah, how it hangs about my Lips.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I hope your Father's well, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: He was three dayes since— I have his Letter for ye, will give you full satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This Favour makes me much his Debtor. Reads. Lor'd, Madam— what does Sir Peregreene mean by all these Ceremonies, he desires you may lodge here with my Sister, till he comes to Town; and does it here with so many reiterated expressions of Obligations receiv'd, that it far exceeds the poorness of the courtesie— I thought he had known, Madam, that his Commands, rather than Intreaties, had been honours to me— Sister, pray see all things provided for my Cousin, and once more welcome to my house.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: You'l find me a bold Guest, Sir— but I am no stranger to your generous temper.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: For my part, I am glad for my own sake, for now I shall have some Company to go and see a Play now and then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Your Friend Val. is struck dumb, prithee speak to him, he's in a fit sure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Heark ye Iack— Prithee what think'st thou of this Lady, Is she not tight, cleanly shap'd, and well rigg'd, ha?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ay, ay,— wou'd I had her in a Sack at my Lodging, I desire no better Company.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But which of e'm do'st like best? deal faithfully.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Why 'faith, to be free with thee, I like e'm both best; I tell ye, I'm a right Rover, I never bestow all my passion upon one: Woman, if there be another in the Company; I don't hold it for good manners.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why merry be thy heart— what now, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Monsieur Thomas is below, and desires to kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Wait on him up; so, now for the Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p:
Heark there, Madam, does not that Sound rejoyce your heart? Monsieur Thomas, your old Gallant— that us'd to Court ye with
Songs; Serenades, Masques, Fiddles, Fa-la's, and the Devil and all, is return'd from Travel, full of the same Virtues he carried with him, and has found you out already.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: I know it— for I unluckily met him, just as I was coming out of the Coach, and he wou'd not let me go till I told him where I was to lodge; I know I shall be troubled with his former Impertinencies; but if I do not fit him—

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Heark! he's coming up— if you han't a mind to see him, 'Tis but stepping here to this Closet, and you may, unknown to him, hear what he sayes.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Madam, will my company breed your diversion, 'faith I'm in Earnest, desire to appear serviceable to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Your Wit, Sir, will be better imploy'd another way; Come Cousin, let's go listen to the Gentleman, no doubt, we shall find a great reformation.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Why, look ye Gentlemen, this is alwayes my damn'd luck, Pox on't, they won't allow me so much as a Leere; but hush— here comes the Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Dear Val, let me have thee in my arms, and there give me leave to tell thee, thou art my best of Friends— What Iack, my Noble Friend, and fellow-Traveller, art thou here too? and my dear Franck? nay then, let us incorporate and make one body, our hearts I know are united already— and let me boldly now confess I'm proud to mingle with such worth and honour.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Here's your Courtier, Gentlemen— but prithee Friend, let's have no more of this; Ceremony among Friends, betrayes as little Love, as Jesting among 'em— thou know'st I love thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith, I believe thou dost— Well Gentlemen, what news then, You that live here in this free thriving Climate, I'm sure you can never want that.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I hear, the King of Poland has receiv'd a considerable loss in a Pitch't Battel— but new Succours lately coming in, 'tis thought he will adventure once more.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: The Grand Signior, they say, is sick too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Is he? why, let him be damn'd too— prithee, what a Devil have thou and I to do with the Grand Signior, or with the King of
Poland's fighting. Why Gentlemen, you mistake me; when I spoke of News, I did not mean what Accidents, or what Battels have been fought; but what Wine, what merry Songs, what good Company, what Women are abroad? there lyes my Province; T'other is fitter for a Grocer, and stinks so of a Coffee-house I hate it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mad Tom still I see— heark ye, Iack Hylas there can help thee to Twenty Women, he's one of their Counsel.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I saw two not long ago that—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hush— Pox on thee thou wilt discover all— but my dear mad Rogue, prithee, what exploits hast thou perform'd since thou hast been absent— I'm sure that story must needs be divertive— come, impart.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not I'faith, I have more modesty than to speak things so much in my own praise, I thank ye-but if thou knew'st all Val— Cou'd I but infuse into thee, the Intrigues, the Rambles, the Serenades, the Quarrels— and the punishment attending 'em, which most valiantly— and 'faith I think much like a Gentleman, I have undergone, and attempted, 'twere enough to put thee into a Feaver; therefore, in pity to thee I'll desist.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, if thou dost not care to speak it thy self, Let thy Man relate it for thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: My Man— why he's the dullest Rogue in the World; We shall have it from him, in a Gallamafry of Languages; prithee observe him, See, how he looks, he's the most Impudent, and withal, the most Ignorant Son of a Whore, that ever I met with. A pox on him, he sticks on me like a Burr, not to be shaken off.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Vat is dis— Vat is de Matra dat they stare upon me, Begar, he be telling some dam Lye now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Come, prithee, let's hear it from him however, It must needs be very divertive.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, for your sake, I'll try him— You shall hear one of my last Frollicks at Paris.— Come Sirrah, you sneaking Dog, advance before me, put your face in a Posture, And then tell it.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Yes,— with all my heart— Serviteur Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, Sirrah, begin.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Vell, Vell— presantly, presantly— hum— but what must me tell— 'tis requisite I shou'd know dat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, Declare, and with rhetorick, tropes, figures, and such like; for if you pronounce it in your every dayes language, I will make your face plainer by a Nose, Rascal— I say, Declare to my Friends here my last Frollick at Paris.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh— de Frollick at Paris— well— now I know what to tell, Let me alone— hum— Gentlemen, the Noble Monsieur my Matra here, going out of his Lodging one Moon-shiné Night, with intent to diverta himself, with the various Object, he very fortunately met in the Street— Who was it you met in the Street— Jernie I have forgot that.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Whore, ye Dog; who shou'd a man meet at that time of Night; I told ye what a dull Rogue he was.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: A Whore; right, a Whore— my Membra be a little short, but that's all one— Vel, dis Whore give him the Jogg— as the damn'd Bitch did to me here in Covent-Garden— t'other Night. He, as a well-bred Gentleman shou'd— followes her, and to say truth, the Woman had a great many divertive, Inscrutable, unintelligable, abominable, Intrinsickable postures with her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What, what's that, Sirrah— Inscrutable, Intrinsickable; bless me, what stuff's this ye Dog?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Vat is it— why do you not know— why, 'tis Rhetorick as you bid me speak; Jernie— you do not know tropes, and figure, when you hear 'em.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What think you now— was there ever such an Insipid Rogue-? you will speak more to the purpose, Rascal, will you not?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Prithee speak it in another language, or in English, if thou can'st, that we may understand the better.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Speak it in an odra Language?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ay, Plainer, in English.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why, so I can Sir, as plain as you if you go to that. Whoo, what a Pox, dee think I can't speak English?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why, ye Impertinent Dog, must I be play'd with all this while, speak quickly, or I will so—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Well, well, Lord you are very Cholerick; so as I was saying Gentlemen, my Master going along with this Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman— what Gentlewoman—? this Whore— Rogue, this Whore— Sirrah, let me have no corruption of Notions— But speak every thing in its Nature— by this Light, Gentlemen, a scurvy Suburb Whore, that smelt of nothing but Tobacco, and Brandy.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
Well, to be short, going farther, we met a Company of fellowes attended by a blind Harper, and a Taber and Pipe, they were bringing along 3 or 4 Bears that were the next day to be baited, my Master presently bargains with 'em for a Pistol to carry this Gentlewoman— this Whore I mean, in triumph home to her Lodging upon
one of the Bears, ha, ha— she was easily perswaded; for the truth is, she was a little too Maudlin to be refractory; my Office was to be Marshal, to keep the Boyes from throwing Eggs, and Tirnups, and he was the Orator to declare her quality— and Virtues— but had you seen the Rabble shouting, the noise that the blind Harper, and Taber and Pipe made, my Master bawling, the Whore singing, and I quarelling among the Boyes, you wou'd have blest your self. Heark ye Sir, shall I tell now how you were beaten, and thrown into a Ditch coming home too?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha! what's that, thrown into a Ditch?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, ay— a sawcy fellow. I threw him into a Ditch, for taking the Wall of me— Sirrah, not a word more of that, as you expect to eat agen— Aside.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Mum, I have done— O Lord, not eat agen?

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Dee hear this Cousin? here's your reform'd Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: He has Travell'd to fine purpose, if this be all he has learnt; I'm glad I've heard this, I might have been mistaken else.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, go you instantly to my Father, and tell him I'm return'd, And sift his Inclination handsomely, that I may know whether his old humour hold, or no; away, by that time you have prepar'd him a little, I ll come, and prosecute; I must have a trick upon him, or I shall get no money.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I am gone Sir— his Father if he be not chang'd since I saw him last, is ten times madder than he; 'tis a strange World this! in a Young Man 'tis Natural, but that an Old Fellow shou'd be so debauch'd— mercy on us, how can he hope to be sav'd? Exit Launce.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, what think you of my Frollick?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Faith, 'twas very extravagant, yet gave occasion for Mirth enough.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ah, I have a thousand of 'em, and as many Mistresses to play upon; but now I talk of Mistresses, I thought I shou'd have seen one of 'em here before now, my Old Love, Val. Madam Cellide, I met her yesterday, and she told me, she was to lodge here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She will not be long from hence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: They have my name in question, and I'll hear what he sayes of me a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I have the honour to have some little knowledge of her; But prithee Tom, how has she entertain'd thee since thy return? for I remember you were alwayes quarrelling together formerly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, that's true, but let me tell you Friend, the case is alter'd now; Why, though we were fallen out, and I have not seen her these six Moneths, yet I prevail'd with her yesterday to go to the Tavern with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How, to th' Tavern?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Heaven! what a ly's this! was ever such Impudence!

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Hush, hear more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: To th' Tavern? Ay, to th' Tavern— and 'faith, between you & I, took off her Bumper as roundly and heartily as one of us cou'd; And believe me, I had a great deal of Joy to see't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— why then I see she cou'd dispence with her Modesty, to give compliance to your Love.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Modesty, what's that, prithee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why a Virtue that is as necessary for young Ladies as their Beauty.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Is it, well, I thank Fortune, and her Education, she understands nothing of it— No, no, she's all free and charming— ah! had'st thou but seen her Eyes sparkling, her Breast panting, her Sighs flowing, her Body trembling, and her Arms twining about me— Ah Rogue— what a Pox, that is not she I hope! Throwes his Arms upon Val, sees Cellide, and starts.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By my faith it is, now I think on't, the very she, the same Obliging, Loving, Flexible Creature you spoke of.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Umph— I am in a fine Condition. Playes with his Hat.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Impudent Detractor! how dare you blast a Ladyes Reputation thus! I at the Tavern? I Kiss ye, and Clasp ye in my Arms? No, I'd sooner do't to my Footman; and were I not certain that these Gentlemen know me better, than to believe a word thou hast said, I wou'd not sleep, till I were reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: So,— will the Devil never leave these tricks?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: It seems, 'tis now your custome to abuse Ladies, but let me tell ye Sir, and with an anger just, and warranted, I am none of those easie Creatures that will suffer such affronts, My Education and Modesty are both proofs against that, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: She carries it well— but if he knew how well she lov'd him, We shou'd have better sport.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why, Hang me, Madam, if I meant any hurt, Tis onely a damn'd way of expressing my self, which I have got.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Curse on your debauch'd Phrases— must my defamation be your way to express your self, you Impudent, base fellow?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why faith, the truth is, I am a very Impudent fellow, This debauch'd World leads us all astray.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: This was certainly a very new way of Courtship, or cou'd you Imagine I wou'd be taken with the Wit on't, when I shou'd happen to hear your Character of me? whatever you think, I know my own mind, and 'tis a question, whether any of your future services will ever be strong enough to blot this affront out of my memory. Exeunt Cellide and Sabina.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Bounce— there goes the Cannon— ha, ha— She was in a plaguy heat Gentlemen, ha, was she not?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It seems so— but what a damn'd lying Rogue art thou, To say thou had'st her at a Tavern?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ay, and that she kiss'd him— and claspt him in her Arms, and drank a Bumper to his health at her first coming in.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: 'Twas well she came in, and hinder'd ye before you cou'd go further, Certainly you must needs have been founder'd, else your lye wou'd have been discover'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No 'faith, all on't was no lye— but I must confess t'ee, under the Rose here, I did stretch a little, as a good teller of a Story shou'd;— for a man can no more tell a good Story; without enlarging upon his Jest— than a Poet can make a good Play, without enlarging upon his Plot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay, let thee alone to bring it off, be it what it will; But come, if thou wilt go in with me, I'll give thee thy Welcome to Town.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, I have business elsewhere; Nor must this angry Beauty sleep in her displeasure— but first to my Father— and whatever you hear of my Actions, Gentlemen, Not a word of my Humour; for though to you I appear a Mad, Wild, Monsieur; To him I must be Ananias— Walk thus— Look thus— Spit thus— I have a Plot in't, and you'l find it your diversion, if you think it worth your patience; for the present, Adieu.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Farewell Wild Oates.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Now to my Sober Look; thus oft we see, The Plodding Fool's the greatest Debauchee. Exit.

div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT II. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: SIrrah, no more of your French shruggs, I advise you. If you are Lowsie, shift your self.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Loosie— Vat a diable— me Loosie— why Monsieur— do you understand who you speak too— me Loosie? Jernie, that is fine indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Let me have no more of your French Grimaces, Rogue, But fetch your Master, your Master, and my Son, body o'me Sir, No money, No more money, Monsieur Launce, not a deneer Sweet, Signior, but bring me instantly my Boy, my mad Tom, Monsieur Thomas, or get you gone agen; Du gat a Whee Sir, Basa mi cu, good Launcelot, Valetote, my Boy, or Nothing.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why so you shall, Sir— but you won'not hear me, because you speak all your self— what a damn'd dull Old fellow this is!

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Why then Sirrah be facetious, and speak quickly, and do not mop, nor mow, nor draw your mouth into a damn'd Posture; Sirrah, I hate all postures; I say be facetious, and quick.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Jernie, why so I will be facetious and quick, if you wou'd holda your Tongue; begar Monsieur, you have the most Eternal Clack— You will let no body speaka but your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Be brief Rogue, be brief.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why then— because your Worships Vulgar Judgment shall meeta me at the nearest— Your Son, my Matra, or Mounsieur Thomas, is at last arriv'd to ask your (as the worthy French man call it) Benediction de jour en jour.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Sirrah, do not conjure me with your French Furies.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Che doga vou rascal, leave your damn'd rotten language, and tell me plainly where your Master is, and why he does not come— or— shall I crack your French Crown? Sirrah— I have maintain'd you and your Monsieur these two years at your Ditty vous, your Iours, Jour me no more; for not another penny shall pass my purse till Thomas comes himself; then, if I find him profited, the Wild, the Wanton, the Mad Tom I wish him— he shall not want the means, whilst I have any; do not answer me, unless in English, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
English— Well, and so I will, and let me tell ye, that 'faith hee'l fit you to a hair— Sir, he was the most debauch'd Fellow in Paris
when he was there such Rearing, such Revelling, such Serenading, and such Whoring; Oh he's a fine man.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Why this is comfort now— there's for thy News; why now I like thee— but Sirrah, is he such a mad Rogue still? Is he my blood, and bones, ha?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I and other Peoples blood and bones too Sir, let me tell you, that— heark ye Sir— give me a Crown to make my self drunk With drinking your health to Night, and I'll tell you— something of him shall make you merry at heart,

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Wilt thou? by Bacchus I'll do't then— there— Come, I stand on thorns to hear it, what is't, what is't?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why Sir— he has had since we left England by Citizens Wives, and their Daughters, private Ladies, and Night Adventurers— Another half Crown Sir— or I can't in conscience tell it else.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Nay, prithee Launce— 'faith, now thou'rt too hard—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Too hard— why, 'tis worth a Pound Sir; 'Faith you shou'd not have it so cheap, but that ye are my Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Pox on thee for a Rogue— there 'tis— come be brief now, What new Prank has the Rogue plaid, ha?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why Sir— by these Women, which I have already mention'd to you, he has had since you saw him last— 4 Bastards, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Four? has he 'faith? ha, ha, ha; by Bacchus, a brave Boy. Four? ha, ha— I am overjoy'd to hear this; But how Launce, how?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why Sir, one of 'em was begot in a Cobler's Stall, Which he broke open for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— So—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Another Sir, upon the Back-Stairs at the Louvre, And the other two in a Church.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— better and better— I am grown young agen at this News— four?— Cock of four— ha, ha,— a Rascal ifaith. Iumps about.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Hush Sir, here he comes— Mum, not a word of this I have told ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: What, my Boy— mad Tom— Monsieur Thomas, I am glad ifaith to see thee, I have wisht for thee, Tom, for you wild Thomas— Tom, I thank thee heartily for coming home.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Be pleas'd to give me your Blessing Sir— Sighs.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p:
Thou hast it, Tom, may'st thou live, and multiply
till thou art a hundred and ten; and as thou art now Cock of four, may'st thou be Cock of Fifty, and sound ones.
I have pray'd for thee, and hope thou art the better for't.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir, I do find your Prayers have much prevail'd above my Sins.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How's this, Sins!— what Sins, Tom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Else surely I had perisht with my rudeness.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha.—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: E're I had won my self to that discretion, I hope you shall hereafter find—

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: What— discretion, oons is it come to that, Sirrah? Launce— Dog— is this the reformation, is this your Cock of four?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Lord Sir, what dee mean, why you mistake your Father clearly; Why, he's as debauch't as you Sir, he likes it in ye, and will cherish it, good Sir, ùnmask, unmask.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah you Rogue— look for't, for I will make thee ten times more miserable than thou thought'st thy self before thy Travel; Thou hast told my Father, I know it, and I find it, all my Rogueries by meer way of prevention, to undo me.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Sir, as I speak Eight Languages, I onely told him you came to ask his Benediction— de jour en jour.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: But that 'tis my duty to be civil now— I wou'd beat thee like a Dog.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: The Devil's in him— this is another Whim now, but I'll be gone, for I'm sure the Old Man's Fingers itch at me, and I think, 'tis not fit that Learning shou'd be beaten. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: However, Sir, the time I have mis-spent, may make you doubtful, Nay harden your belief gainst my Conversion.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Forgive me!— Conversion!— this is worst of all— O Pox on Travel, I say.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Yet, dear Father, your own experience in my after-courses, and observation of my Life and Carriage, may yield some satisfaction; for I'll reform my self in every thing: I won'not be drunk, nor swear, nor Wench, Pray forgive me Sir, Indeed I will no more be so forgetful, hah. Sighs.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha— the Devil ha ye, and the Pox too— spoyl'd, quite spoyl'd, for ever lost; a Plague of Travel, If this be the fruits on't.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Let not your Ears be open to my Enemies, he leads an ill life Sir, that never mends— there are a sort of sober Men i'th Town,
which the Rabble call Phanaticks; these I will follow to instruct my self— and you shall see me mount the losty Hogshead, and teach, and preach, and sing, and say, and pray,—

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: And ha, and Yea, and Nay, and Fool, and Ass, and Coxcomb. Mocks him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, ay Sir— you have reason to be angry, but let Religion tell ye I am your Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ye lye Sir, and get you out of my doores— I disclaim ye; Undone, without redemption! hang him, he'l drink by Thimbles full— like a sneaking Rascal— how the Devil have I sinn'd, that this affliction shou'd light so heavy on me? Well, I'll go seek an Heir— I am resolv'd on't, for my Inheritance must not turn Secretary; my Name and Quality has kept my Land three hundred years in Madness— and if it slip now, may it sink for ever— But first, I'll find out this lying Rogue, this Dog, this Launce, that took my money, and then fool'd me— I'll find him, and I'll cudgel him to Mummy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha ha ha, this verifies the Old Proverb, No Impudence like that hid under the Vizor of Zeal. A sudden compliance will now make him part from his Estate more willingly, but the time is not come yet— I must amuse him a little longer— my dear Sister— I am glad to to see thee, did'st thou meet my Father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, but very angry to my thinking.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith, he does ill in't, for I was uttering a handsome speech or two— I have been studying e're since I come from Paris; but how do'st thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Very well, and gladder to see you, and with more Love, I dare affirm it, than my Father's sorry, to see, as he supposes, your Conversion; I am sure he is vext to'th Heart.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Nay, I know it, He has pray'd against it strongly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I warrant thee, let me alone— I can bring all off when I list, and yet be mad too; ah Doll, ever take a Traveller for a Plot— but heark ye, I have a little business for thee.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Yours, is my business, speak, and be obey'd; You know I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ah poor Soul! 'Faith, thou art a dear Rogue to me; Well, you partly may guess this; 'tis concerning my Old Mistress, Madam Cellide.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Oh Sir, are you there already— what, some small affront to her I'll lay my life— and I'm to be Arbitrator.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith thou art in the right— and 'tis but a small matter— but you know she's so pettish—

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Some lye— or defamation of her, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, faith, no, a petty business, a flight matter; but however, to make all well agen— I have writ her a Letter here, and my Suit to thee, is to be Emissary— thou canst hit her humour right, and I'm sure will put in a Word or two (by the by) for me, for old acquaintance sake.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'll do what I can, but I assure ye, she has heard of all your mad Tricks, the Gambols you have play'd since your departure, in every Town you came, your several Mischiefs, your Rowses, and your Wenches; all your Quarrels too, and the no causes of 'em— Your fame came over before ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Whoo Pox— lyes, damn'd lyes— prithee tell her I am converted now; Not like the man I was: Thou had'st a pretty faculty of swearing once, Prithee try— Pox, what's an Oath or two to oblige a Brother— Pshaw, pshaw, 'tis nothing— I'll swear an hour together for thee at any time.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: A very friendly offer; Well Sir, though I will not promise ye to swear as you request— yet perhaps I may do your business as well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Wilt thou?— why a blessing on thy heart, and 'faith to requite thee, if there be e're a tall, handsome, Well sett brisk Fellow— better than ordinary about Town, I'll get him for thee, that thy business may be done too.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, there's two Ladies below come to Visit ye.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Ten to one 'tis they, and my trouble of going is sav'd; Tell her I'll come.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll not be seen— 'twill look like modesty in me, and play but thy part now dear Rogue, and command me for ever. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What, still this mopeing alone my dear— why sure you have forgot what diversion or good Company means, or do ye intend to turn Nun, and exclude your self from the World, and now practising Austerity?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p:
Neither of these assure your self; for first, I love Company too well, to take my self from 'em, that am or desire to be a Considerable Subject; and secondly, I love my self too well to exclude it from pleasing
Society, through any aversion I have for the World, or any passion for the Nunnery you speak of.

sp.speaker: Cellide.
sp.p: I am very glad I am mistaken; but hearkee, do'st thou want e're a Trick, a Design, a Plott, to bubble thy Servant, or so?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Not I indeed— but how dee mean to Bubble him?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Why, cause him to stand in the Snow at thy Chamber Window all Night long, to make him temperate— or make him Jump over thy Turky Chairs in the Parlour, and break his Shins, to try his Activity— or tye his hands behind him, and then break his head with the Hilt of his own Sword, to try his Valour, and Patience;— or hast thou occasion for a Lye— a Womans Lye? that is, a loud, malitious— swinging lye— a lye that has stuff enough, and is not spoil'd in the making— if thou hast, speak, and if I do not fit thee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, when I want, I'll not fail to make use of your offer. But I am now imploy'd upon a business— and though you think me so retir'd a Person, to say truth, I was just going out before you came, and coming to you, I have a Letter for ye.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: A Letter?

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: A Billet Doux— from some unknown Gallant I warrant that was surpriz'd in the Country.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: No, he was surpriz'd in Town, I can assure you that, and he's a Relation of mine.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Oh, are ye thereabouts— nay then I begin to smell the Jest, There is a Wild Monsieur, a Brother of yours— that's newly return'd from Travel, one that I confess has a better faculty at lying, than I have; and for defaming Ladies, debauching their Women, beating Constables, breaking Glass Windows— the most accomplish'd that ever came from Paris.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: For what he has done, I have nothing to say, but onely for what he is now; and though I am his Sister, I dare assure you, never was man so much alter'd in so short a time; he is grown the most sober, civil, well behav'd, courteous Man you ever saw— Prithee read the Letter, there you'l find more of him.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: 'Tis a riddle to me he shou'd be so, he was yesterday quite another thing to my knowledge; and to leap in an instant from an excess of Wildness, to the extream of Temperance, is to me a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I thought as much— his Letter speaks a very civil, reform'd Creature indeed; read it, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: What, Complement, I warrant, some Wretched piece of Poetry.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Oh, an Excellent piece— ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dor.
sp.p: Dammee Madam— If I were a Poet, I wou'd be more Elegant; But confound me, you know I am not; Was ever such a thing writ?— is this his modesly in the devils name?

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Well, what think ye now, is not the Gentleman a great Convert?— ha, ha, ha,— there is an Old Proverb, What is bred in the Bone, will never— you understand me, and therefore prithee trouble thy self with no more Embassies, but next time, let him make his Address himself— Come, put on thy Scarf, and let us take a pair of Oars to Fox-Hall, 'Tis a fine Evening, and I know we shall be merry.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Well, what you please— but in my opinion the Park is the better place of the two: What thinkest thou, my Dear?— hey day, why thou art not grown Melancholick about this simple Letter, art?— Come, prithee sing us a Scotch Song, I know thou art good at it.

lg.l: ABroad as I was walking upon a Summer Day,
There I met with a Beggar-woman cloathed all in gray;
Her Clothes they were so torn, you might have seen her skin.
She was the first that taught me to see the Golin.
Ah see the Golin, my Io, see the Golin.
You Youngsters of delight, pray take it not in scorn,
She came of Adam's Seed, though she was basely born:
And though her Cloathes were torn, yet she had a Milk-white skin,
She was the first, &c.
She had a pretty little Foot, and a moyst Hand,
With which she might compare to any Lady in the Land;
Ruby Lips, Cherry Cheeks, and a Dimpled Chin,
She was the, &c.
Whan that ay had wooed her, and wad her twa my will,
Ay could not then devise the way to keep her Baby still.
She bid me be at quiet, for she valued it not a Pin,
She was, &c.
Then she takes her Bearn up, and wraps it weel in Clothes,
And then she takes a Golin and stuck between her Toes;
And ever as the Lurden cry'd, or made any Din,
She shook her Foot and cry'd my Jo, see the Golin.
Ah see the Golin my Jo, see the Golin.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Heark! what's the matter? A noise within.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Rogue— Dog, Lying Rascal. within.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Tis my Father's voice, he's angry with some body, Come, let's be gone; for if he sees me, I shall not get out these two hours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Sirrah, am I to be baffled?— must I give Money to give your Dogship occasion to laugh at me in a Corner: What, I am a Fool, am I? fit to be bubbled?— no Rogue, Instead of tutoring your Master, I find you have spoil'd him.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ay, spoila him— make a dat out— Jernie, I can bring sufficient Evidence, he did spoila me the first week I came to him— You don't remember when he made the Ten Whores in Whetstones Park stand every one on their heads upon Quart-Pots, you are Ignorant of that, but I'm sure I remember it; for I got a damn'd clap dat time, which I cou'd never claw off since: besides, how cou'd I spoila him?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Oh, I'll tell you how, Sirrah— first, thou hast taught him, like an Insipid Rascal, to read perfectly, which, on my blessing I warn'd him from; for I knew, if he came to read once, he was a lost Man. Secondly, Sir Launcelot, Sir Lowsie Launcelot— You have suffer'd him against my power, first then— against my Precept— to keep that sort of People company, which sober Men call civil, mark ye that Sir.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why then, the Divla fetch me, if to my knowledge he does not hate all Civil Company; he never was civil in his life, nor never will be— Oons I saw him break a Parson's head t'other day but for praying him to be Civil to his Wife, whom he was going to be uncivill to before his face.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I know you have your come offs and your lyes, But it shant do, this is like your Cock of Four, Sirrah, I remember that your Cock— but I'll make you Cock of Five before we part; I'll teach you to play your Tricks with me.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Vat trick?— me play no trick— begar 'tis he dat do play all the trick— is dere no hole, or Corner?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p:
Thirdly, and lastly Sirrah— which if the Law were here I'd hang thee for— (however I will lame thee) Like a Rascal thou
hast wrought him— clean to forget what 'tis to do a mischief— a handsome mischief, and such as thou know'st I love well; my Servants are all sound now, my Drink sower'd, not a Horse pawn'd, or plaid away; no Warrants come for the breach of Peace; Men Travel with their Money, Nothing meets 'em: I was accurs'd to send thee with him, thou wer't ever leaning to Laziness, and loss of spirits, and sleep'st still like a Cork upon the Water.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: O Lord, O Lord, I sleep— why Sir, all the Town knowes that next to him— there is not such a debauch'd— Lew'd Fellow in Christendom as I am— I may thank him for't, if I am damn'd. Why Sir, did you never hear of my Astrology?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Thy Astrology?— dull Rogue, thou wou'dst make a rare Astrologer!

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Vat— you mock me then— a cursed simple old fellow this, Yes Sir, I tell ye I am fam'd for Astrology— I can tell any Woman her fortune, and her constitution too, whether hot, or dry; or cold, or moyst; or whether she is honest, or dishonest— Jernie, if I can get her alone with me, I'll quickly tell her, whether she is a Whore, or no.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: I tell ye, I know you can prate well enough, but that she-shan't save ye— ha— is that Tom— No, that— Enter Thomas. sneaking, snivelling Puppy can ne're be Monsieur Thomas, sure: Turn you yonder, Sirrah— and see who's there; there's your Reformer— does he look like a Cock of four, ye Dog?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What sweet content dwells here?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oons, put up your Book Sir! What, what's this Baxters Call? Baxter's Coxcomb— here, here— give't me, and here's Aratine's Book of Postures for ye— take it, We are all Undone else.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh profane Rogue— there Sirrah, for ye. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh! what shall I do, I shall be murder'd at this rate.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Tom, When is the Horse-Race?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I know not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: No— why, you'l be there I hope?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not I— I have forgot those Journeys, thank my Fortune:

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Undone, without redemption— the Cocking holds at Derby too, Tom, and there will be Iack Hylas, and Will. Purser.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Hah— I am sorry, Sir, They shou'd employ their precious time so vainly, Their Understandings will bear better courses.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p:
Yes, I will marry agen, I am resolv'd on't; but Son Thomas,
what say ye to the Gentleman that challeng'd ye before ye went about your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh good Sir— remember not those Follies where I have done wrong— so much I now have learn't to discern my Self, my Means, and my Repentance shall make even Sir; Nor do I think it any Imputation to let the Law perswade me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, the Law? the Law's an Ass as thou art; Did ever such affliction light on Man? Well, any Woman, I care not of what colour or constitution, if she can but bear Children, 'faith I'll have her. Exit Sir Wild.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh I am glad he's gone— I have had such an Ague upon me— but good Sir, what dee mean by this? You have utterly undone me, I shall be for the Ragged Regiment within these two dayes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, he fiets to some purpose; but art thou such an Insipid Rascal to mind it? What, Eight Languages, and tremble at an Old Man's Threats?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Not at his Threats, but his Blowes, Sir, I know them too well to be mistaken; 'tis not Eight, nor Eightscore can keep me from beating, if not killing; I'll give him leave to break a Legg, and thank him, pull off my Hatt, and cry, God bless his Worship. You might have sav'd all this, and but sworn a little— What a Pox had an Oath or two been to you when your hand was in, or a head broke— though it had been mine, to have satisfi'd the Old Gent. a little.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, faith, to do thee a kindness, I'll break it yet.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Phoo, Pox now 'tis too late— but Sir, will you do me one favour, will you be drunk to night?— a less intreaty has serv'd your turn to my knowledge— do it, and save all yet: Yet do not be mad-drunk, for then you are the Devil; Yet the Drunker, the better for your Father still. Your State is desperate Sir, and with a desperate Cure we must recover it— good Sir, do something, some debauch't drunken thing, some mad thing, or some any thing to help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, go, for a Fidler then— the blind Old Fidler, under the Church Wall— he that saves his Songs— and dee hear, get me a Whore or two— a good, full, fat Whore, One that is fleshy; let her be an Old Bawd, so she be fat enough— I care not.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why I— this is well sed now, Sir I thank ye heartily, and I'll about it presently. Knock within.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Ha! Somebody knocks— go, let 'em in, who ere it be, and then make haste. Exit Launce. My Father's mad now— and ten to one, will dis-inherit me;
I'll put him to plunge once more, and by that time my Design will be full ripe— how now, how do'st thou Iack?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Why 'faith, at the same pitch still— I neither wane not thrive.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O Sir, I have been with the Physitians, and they are all ready below here. To Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Go, direct 'em to my house, and desire 'em to take all possible Care in the Recovery of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Physitians! for what prithee— whos's Dog lyes sick of the Mulligrubs?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Whoo, prithee, leave thy vile Phrases,— 'tis a Friend of yours, I assure you, Franck Welbred— he was taken extreamly ill of a Fever yesterday, and lyes very weak at my house.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Who young Franck? the onely temper'd, Spirit, Scholar, Souldier, Courtier, and all in one piece, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You'l find it true— but who's this?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Heark ye, Sir, a word wee '.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh, Dear Rogue, art thou come already— well, of all Women, thou for dispatch sha't be most fam'd; and what success, prithee?— how did she like my Letter?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Like it, infamous Man!— do you not blush at your Ingratitude? had you no one to abuse with the carriage of your debauch'd Epistle, but your Sister? must I be your Property? because you found my easie Nature, willing to oblige— wou'd you affront me so? this baseness is hardly to be parallel'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By her vehemence in action, this shou'd be something of Moment, Iack.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I know not what her action is— but she has a fine Buttock I'm sure, I have been looking at that.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Hey-day, I affront thee? prithee what do'st thou mean, Sister?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: You wou'd be told, wou'd you? You have forgot, I warrant. But come, to refresh your memory, I'll read your worthy piece to you, Your Letter of Address to a Lady, whom you have abus'd— Your sweet Ticket of Repentance, and Reconciliation— Pray observe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, with all my heart,
Zoux Madam, if I were a Poet, the Devil take me if I wou'd not be more Elegant. A very fine beginning, Is it not?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith I think so— without I shou'd have begun with— After my hearty Commendations; or, Surely; and, By my truly Mrs.— but go on—

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: But, Confound me, You know I am none; and by the Beard of Iupiter, I am the less able to pen my excuse. ‛ S' Death, Madam, You know like a Devil as you are, I love you dearly. There, there, what occasion for that Oath, that Culverin there?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why, to tell thee the truth▪ I swore in that place, because I wou'd have her sure to believe me.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Very well; and by the Sun, the Moon, the Planets, the Stars, the Meteors— and such like, I am sorry for my last fault— And sinck me, am thy Devoted Servant both in this World— and in t'other. Oh horrible, is not that now monstrous lewd and wicked?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No 'faith— Methinks 'tis very pretty— I have given her occasion there to see my Wit, and Learning.

Therefore, by the Eternal Blazing-Starr, that is to Convert the whole World into a Snuff-box, either instantly pardon me, or expect to be hourly molested, by the most passionate, and most resolute of his Sex; and so I leave ye to enter into consideration, and retire my self to my place of residence, the Devil-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: What think you now? speak, In your Conscience, Is not this a Rare Piece?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, the Devil take me if it be not the fairest, noblest and most lofty style that ever was writ— Well— Doll— I will pardon thy Ignorance, and hers too; but in troth you are both very silly Creatures.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What you please Sir, let me have no more such Messages, and then you'l favour me— I'll instantly to my Father, and tell him to his great Joy of heart— You are his true Son still— the same for lying, Swearing, Drinking, Wenching, you ever was: And now I talk of Wenching— give me leave to inform ye— Your Young Rear-Admiral— I mean your last Bastard, Don Iohn, ye had by Lady Blanch, the Dairy-Maid— is by an Academy of Learn'd Gypsies stolne from the Nurse, and wanders with these Prophets. This in conclusion, I thought good to tell ye, and so your humble Servant, Sir. Exit Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Plaguy smart Jilt— but this is her Minute, the next is mine, and I have a design in my head, if follow'd well, shall bring all about yet. Come Iack.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Where, where's the Lady?— what, thou hast not let her go, hast?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Let her go? why 'twas my Sister.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ah, is she thy Sister? nay then e'en let her go.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen— I must beg your pardon— I must go see Franck.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Stay Val, a word first; heark ye— I'll go with thee; To Visit him, will be an excellent pretence of Introducing me into my Mistresses sight— and if I can but once more see her.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay 'faith, I am so much thy Friend, I'll hinder thee nothing— Come then wee'l all go.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You shall see me cut upon her Heart, like a Diamond on Glass— I know her humour to a thought.

lg.l: With brisk behaviour, loud Impertinence
I'll Court her, her own way, much noise, small sence;
For I've observ'd 'tis not the Man of Parts,
But your fine Talker, gets the Ladies hearts.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Franck Sick in a Chaire, a Bed standing by.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: A Pleurisie, I see it.

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: I rather hold it for Tremor Cordis.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: Dee' mark the Foeces? 'tis a most pestilent Contagious Fever— a Surfeit, a Plaguy Surfeit, he must bleed.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: By no means—

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: I say Bleed.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: I say 'tis dangerous, the person being so much spent before-hand, Hypocondriaque humours being now in full Power, and Nature drawn so low— No, I rather think Clysters, cool Clysters.

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: Now, with your favours— I shou'd think a Vomit; for, take away the Cause, the Effect will follow; his Stomach's foul, and the Intellect inflam'd.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: No, no, wee'l rectifie that part by milder means.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: Come Sir, you must have patience; Brother, I think we had best first clap on the Cataplasme.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen, good Learned Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: And see those Broaths made ready within this hour; Come Sir, pray be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Pray Sir will you leave me; I beseech you leave me: Convey your Cataplasmes to those that need 'em, your Vomits, and your Clysters.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: Bring in the Lettuce Caps— You must be shav'd Sir, and then wee'l make you sleep.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Ay, till Dooms-day— What unnecessary Nothings are these?

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: How do ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What Questions they propound too— how do you Sir, I'm glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: Open your Mouth, I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Aw— well, can you tell me now how old I am?— There's my hand, pray shew how many broken shins I shall have within these two year— 'S'Death, who wou'd be thus in Fetters, good Mr. Doctor, and you Dear Doctor, and the third sweet Doctor, and precious Master Pothecary, I beseech ye to give me leave to live a little longer— You stand before me like my Mourners.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: A great Distemper, his fancy now begins to turn too. Enter Monsieur Thomas, Valentine, and Hylas Kew. Pish, what more hindrance still?— Sir— 'tis not our Custome to be rude— but dismiss your Company with what haste you can; for we must minister within this half hour. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Oh,— a fair riddance, my learned Horse-leeches.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Be not uncivil, Tom,— and use your pleasure— I know she will be here to visit him within this half hour: Do what you can to win her, but use no violence.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I will not 'faith.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where, where's this Sick Man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Where are the Women, Man? there's my Province. Methinks these Women—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thou think'st nothing else.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: See Franck— here's two of thy Friends come to visit thee; Prithee look up— and bid 'em welcome— I'll go and see if they have got any thing for thee to eat— Come, sit up, and be merry, Man.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How do'st thou, Franck, ha?
Come, give me thy hand, and bear up boldly— what, shrinck ith' Sinews for a little Sickness? a petty, puny, paultry Fever— Pox upon't, sing it away, Man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I am on the mending hand, I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How like a Flute thou speak'st, on the mending hand? Gogs boars I'm well— Speak like a Man of honour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Thou art a Mad Fellow; what, never staid. Tom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Let Rogues be stai'd that have no habitation, a Gentleman may wander— turn thee round, Franck— and see what I have brought thee— Sirrah, open the Scene and let the Work appear— Francis, a Friend at need is worth a Million. Boy discovers a Bottle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What hast thou there, a Julip?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: He must not touch it, 'tis present Death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ye are an Ass—
Thou minister? thou mend a Pack-Saddle-You must pardon him— my Friend Franck— but a plaguy simple Fellow.
Do'st thou see this Bottle?— Prithee view it well; Agen observe it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Well, I do, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: There are as many Lives in't as a Cat carries; It refines the Spirit, revives the Person, removes the Disease, Restores the blood; heats, nourishes, fills the Veins, Cures, comforts, warms, purges— hey— in fine, 'tis everlasting Liquor— and shou'd be spoken of with reverence.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Prithee what is't?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why 'faith— Old Sack.
Old Spirit stirring Oyly, reverend Sack— which, maugre any thing I can read yet, was the Philosopher's Stone The Wife King Ptolomy did all his Wonders by.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Nay, I see no harm Sir— if drunk with moderation.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Moderation!— Drink with Walnuts, Man, which I have ready here, and a Glass too; take me Sits down on the Stage, and pulls out Walnuts— and a Glass. without my tools, and hang me.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, use temperance, You know your own state best.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Temperance!— ugh, ugh— Pox on him, I had like to bin choak't with a Wall-nut-shell— by giving ear to his damn'd temperance.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I thank thee, Iack— I shall be careful— Yet a Glass or two can do no harm, your Friend Tom is grown very sober.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A fool, a fool, he minds nothing now Speaks this as he is Cracking the Nuts. but Jelly-broth a mornings, and Bulking Whores at Night— Never cares for good Company, Fiddles, nor Glasses now— a very Coxcomb, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Where the Devil are these Women all this while?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, no, take my Counsel, Franck,
sp.p: Hang up your Julips, and your Portugal Possets, Your Barly Broths— and Sorrel Sops; I hate 'em— they are mangy and breed the scratches onely— I wonder she does not come all this while— Come Franck, here's to thee.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: With all my heart— and methinks I feel a strange alteration on the sudden— my pulse beats quick, and lively.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: So long, and yet no bolting. Peeping about.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, I knew 'twou'd come to that— my presence is a Never-failing Cordial to both Sexes; here, take this off thrice, and then cry Heigh, like a Huntsman, with a clear heart, and no more fits I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: Are the things ready? and is the Barber come?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: An hour ago, Sir?

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: Bring out the Oyles, then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: S'death— here agen!— Now, or never, Tom, do me a kindness, and deliver me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Deliver thee,— from whom?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: From these things that talk there, Physitians, Tom, Scouring-sticks, they mean to read upon me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll do't,— Come hither, Iack.

sp.speaker: 1 Phys.
sp.p: We desire all to depart the Room, and no longer disturb the Patient.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Strike in with me for your part, and let us play upon these Rogues a little— for Look ye Doctor, suppose the Devil were sick now— his horns saw'd off, and his head bound with a Biggen— sick of a Calenture taken by a Surfeit of stincking Soules at his Nephews, and St. Dunstans, what wou'd you minister upon the sudden? Your Judgment short, and sound.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: A Fool's head.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, Sir,— it must be a Physitian, for three causes; the first, because it is a ball'd head likely— which will down easily without Apple pap.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: A main cause.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: So 'tis, and well consider'd,
The second Cause, 'tis fill'd with broken Greek, Sir,
Which will so tumble in his stomach, Doctor, and Jumble and work upon the Crudities, the Faeces, and the Fiddle-strings, conceive me Doctor, that of meer reason they must dis-imbogue.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Or meeting with the Stygian humour.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Forc'd with a Cataplasme of Crackers.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ever.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Scour all before him, like a Scavenger.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Satis fecisti Domine— my last Cause.
My last, and not my least, most Learned Doctors,

Because in most Physitians heads— I mean those that are most excellent— and Old withal— and angry; I say, because in most Doctors heads, there is a kind of Toadstone Bread and Crust, Sir,— whose virtue— the Doctor being stript and laid upon a Grid-iron

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: What's that, Sir!— a Grid-iron?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Grid-iron, Sir! the Learned hold it necessary, then by an Instrument of his own Barber, his Nose being slit, incis'd, his Mouth gagg'd open, and his most bawdy excremental Tongue— bray'd in a Mortar— to Powder— the Cure's infallible, Not to be question'd.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: Bless me! what stuff's here? Mad Sir! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Onely a Question— Nothing else— for say the belly ake caus'd by an Inundation of Pease Porridge.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: This is not civil.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I think not— that's all one: Or grant the Diaphragma by a Rupture—

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: The Sign being then in the head of Capricorne.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Meet with the Passion Hypocondriaca, and so cause a Carnosity in the Kidneys, must not the Brains being butter'd with this humour cause a Cathartique Motion? answer me that.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: What shall we answer ye? what shall I say? Ye are an Ass, will that satisfie ye?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Out still— for the Ass is yours by your long Ears, your Nose too which I will pull thus into form, and take possession of a Sattin Cap to give your thick Skull, and your Brains more aire.

sp.speaker: 2. Phys.
sp.p: Come, come, let's be gone Sirs, we are abus'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No 'faith, not yet, but shall be in good time— then if my Ladies Dog be laxative, troubled with qualms, grumblings, Windy Cholicks, Doctor; are ye therefore to open the Port Vein, or the Port Esquiline? your answer quickly.

sp.speaker: 3. Phys.
sp.p: I'll answer no more— farewel, Sir, the next Fit you have, Bedlam shall find a Salve for; we came to do you good, But these young Roarers it seems have bor'd our Noses.

sp.speaker: 1. Phys.
sp.p: Drink hard, and get unwholsome Wenches, 'tis ten to one then we shall hear further from your note alter'd. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And wilt thou be gone, sayes one?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: And wilt thou be gone, sayes t'other?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Then take the odd Crown, to mend thy old Gown, And wee'l be all gone together.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— most excellent Rogue, I love thee heartily for this.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, the Young Ladie— sent me to see what Company ye had with ye— and whether they may make a Visit?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Pray tell 'em, with all my heart— they'l much honour me in't— You see my Company.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come hither Crab— is not my Mistress one of 'em?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: And who else?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Madam Sabina▪

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh— heark Sirrah, not a word of my being here; Take that, and Mum.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: You have ty'd my Tongue up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ah— nay if you look so brisk, farewel the Fever, Friend.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Nay, I am much better, thank my Dear Tom here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The Game is ready to begin, your Mistress is coming.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I know it, therefore sit still good Franck, and not a word of me till you hear from me— then as you find my humour, follow it. You two come with me, and let us stand close, unseen— I warrant thee I catch her. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: How dee' Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: The favour of this Visit from you, Madam, gives me strength to tell ye, That my Enemy has done his worst; I am growing well agen.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it— Were you ever sick before, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Of Love, Madam, not else.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Of Love? Alas! for ye— but you had good hopes of your side▪ You know 'twas no Epidemick distemper; for 'tis as impossible, a man shou'd dye by Love, as that he shou'd live by it— and either of these are Miracles this Climate never produces.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, no— I have no hope, nor is it fit Friend— my life has been so lewd, my loose condition, which I repent too late, so abominable, That nothing but despair stands now before me.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Who's that, Sir— another Sick Man?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: In all my Courses shameless— disobedience.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Sure, I shou'd know his voice— Pray, Sir, who is't?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: One that you little thought to have seen in such a condition; 'Tis the Wild Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Who my Monsieur?— Monsieur Thomas? ha, ha, ha, this is some trick.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You'l think better, when you see him— he was seiz'd yesterday with a strange distraction— a perfect madness.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: That's like enough— he has been seiz'd with that, ever since I knew him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Not in this Nature, Madam; he is now, since he came to himself, much afflicted in's mind— he came hither to ask pardon of me for some things done long since, which his distemper made to appear like wrongs; but 'twas not so.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Sure that is not possible.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Here he comes— Pray observe him.

div.stage: Enter Thomas as distracted, Valentine, Hylas.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Come, Sir, be comforted.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: To what end, Gentlemen— when all is perish't upon a wrack. Is there a hope remaining, the Sea, that never knew sorrow shou'd be pitiful— my Comfort's gone, my Life has made me Wretched— Nor is it possible, were I to live Ten Ages, Ever to recall the least part of my Follies.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh you despair too much. Madam, you see his condition, One word from you may yet recover him.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: I know not what to do, nor what to think— I am amaz'd 'twixt pity and admiration.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: If it be real, 'tis no Jesting matter; a Man is not so soon made, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What are these Ladyes?— I had a Sister once, a Virtuous Sister, But I abus'd her— poor Soul, I wrong'd her— a Mistress too, a Kind sweet Beauteous Mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now, Madam, now's your time; now he's talking of ye.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: I'll do any thing, rather than see him thus.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I wrong'd her too— I sent her a damn'd Letter full of Oaths, Wrack't her poor Innocent Ears with Damms and Devils, Wo worth the time I did so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now, Madam, speak, or never.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: By Heaven, I will; ah little do you know how my heart bleeds for him.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— she comes apace— the Rogue counterfeits rarely.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh my fortune. But 'tis but Just I be despis'd and hated.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Despair not, 'tis not Manly— Now Madam.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: How dee' Sir? pray be comforted— give me your hand— you us'd to meet this kindness with more haste; I swear I pity ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: By Heaven 'tis she— oh goodness! not to be equall'd— let me thus low implore thy pardon; I have been wild and wicked, I confess it, but ah dear Saint, consider on our frailties; Youth often wanders from the way, and—

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, you shan ' not kneel.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Not kneel? oh name it not, my Crimes are many, and nothing but repentance, low repentance— Iack.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I, I mind ye— proceed and she's thy own, Boy.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Nay then I'll kneel too— for I have faults too many, I shou'd beg your pardon too, all things consider'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Precious— Dearest, Lovely— Charming— Ah, Kisses her. all my whole lifes service— cannot merit half, half this blessing.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Where, where's my Master?— oh Sir— the Fidler, Sir, is not at leisure yet, but he will be about half an hour hence. But I have got Sir, according to your order, a couple of the finest Black fat Whores yonder— 'gad the Jades do so tumble about— ha, ha— both start.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Damn'd Dogg— Kicks him.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: 'S'death— this damn'd dull Rogue will spoil all— what, what's that you say, Sirrah? who wou'd you speak with, ha?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, an Impudent Dog, who wou'd he speak with?— here's no body here knowes him— Kick him out o' doors there.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: What, not know Launce?— I am Launce, Sir, and a Pox take me, if I have not two of as fine fat Whores as a man wou'd desire to lay his Leg over.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I'm betray'd! and this was onely a design upon me. I find it now 'tis so, Cousin— oh I cou'd curse my self now for being so credulous— this was a Plot betwixt 'em, and now by chance discover'd; stand off, and touch me not, Base Fellow— Come, let's away— Farewel Sir, and when you are mad next— let your fat Whores administer.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— this was a pleasant Jest. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come ye hither, Sirrah, and lay your head down on this Chair, I'll be merciful to ye— I'll onely cut your Ears and Nose off; Your head shall scape— doo't quickly, Rogue, or I will hew thee into Mammocks.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh for Heavens sake, Sir, what mean ye? You know I did nothing but what you bid me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ah— Insipid Whelp.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Hang him, let him wear his Nose a little longer— 'Twill spoyl the fashion of his face else.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Though 'twas unluckily, 'twas Ignorantly done, and let him live to make amends.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pox on't— when I had bent her like a twigg— brought her to my hand— made her quite sure, my own, with art and Industry, and to be bubbled of her in the very last moment, by the negligence of a Dog, a Hound, a Son of a Whore, a plague— Prithee Val, let me have but one pass through his Guts, and I'll forgive him.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen, for heavens sake hold him— for my guts are so empty, that he may easily rip 'em open.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Come forgive him— the Rogue I dare swear did it out of meer Kindness.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: By my Eight Languages, and so I did— I was so overjoy'd to bring him the good News, that I never minded who was with him▪

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Devil on't— this is alwayes my damn'd fortune, and I have still observ'd if a Fool be in a Family— where any Person has a design— if his Ignorance does not discover it, his ill fortune will— and that's as bad— Well, I am resolv'd she shan'not scape thus— I will have one more bout with her. You will not leave me, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I 'faith; I will not miss the sport.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Nor I— but when shall it be?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: To Night at her Window in a Serenade.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: With all our hearts— Franck, wou'd thou wer't well to go too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I know not, 'tis as I feel my self— but it may be I may venture, For I can walk I find.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Go Dog, get you to my Father, and tell him my last Nights Ramble, I'll come and second ye; away— I shall get the Rogue this way a beating at the second hand.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. I am glad I'm got off so well; for I was damnably afraid of losing my Ears, and Nose. Well Sir, I'll go and carry the Whores to the same Bulk, where I found 'em, and then let 'em seek their fortune. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, that shall be my task.
Come Friends, let's prepare for the business; till Night I am employ'd— but then I am for ye. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Wilding with a Whore, Boy with a Candle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Now to the business of Matrimony— I think I have got one here will fit me— I pickt her up in the Piazza's, what she is I know not, nor do I care— so she be fruitful and sound— Set down the Candle, Sirrah, and get you gone— Come hither Mistress— Let me see your Face— those Eye-browes are your own, I hope?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you, Sir— I counterfeit nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Very well— now walk before me— let me see you pace a little. ah— trip— trip— thus, thus— I wou'd have my Woman do so.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Sir, I shall quickly learn to please ye, there shall be nothing wanting in my duty, to act, or to observe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Prettily said— as to your age, Madam, I guess you to be about Five and twenty— something over— a good ripe age, I like that well enough— Pray open your Mouth; I think you have all your teeth.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: I hope so, Sir— they have had easie service.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: And wilt thou sing?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Pleasantly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: And drink?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Profoundly.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: And swear— and tell a Story after Supper?

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: As you think fit, Sir— by the way of rellish, or so.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Give me thy hand then, she's honest, I know by that; for she that simpers, and talks of Religion alwayes, proves to be the greatest Jilt— who waits there?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Bid my Daughter come hither— now I think I shall be even with my Monsieur— my sneaking Ananias: For I will get upon her Body▪ Demi-Gyant that shall play the Hector at his Nurses Breast, and beat a Constable in his swadling Cloathes. Enter Mrs Dorothy. Come hither Mistress— pray respect the Lady whom I intend to make my Wife, your Mother.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: How Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Now you shall find me so then— what a pox, d'ee think I'll leave my Inheritance to Pins, and Bodkins, to Towers, Jesamine Gloves, and Trimmings— to a leaky Vessel— that cannot keep my name up when I dye to thee?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: You have a Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Who?— where is he? who is he like?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Your self.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Thou ly'st— thou hast spoyl'd him, Thou, and thy Prayer-Books;— he my Son? No, I disclaim him, And all that speaks of him. Why, did not I catch him singing yesterday a godly Ballad, to a godly tune too, and in one of his Pockets a Catachisme with the Creed in great Letters at the beginning?— No, Damsel of the dark— I know he's one of your Disciples, he wou'd be rul'd else.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Mine?— 'tis a sign then you know little of his humour, That can believe I have power to turn him any way.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Huswife I know it, and expect to be rewarded, what Tavern has he us'd since he came over? what things done, that showes a Man and Mettle? when was my house at such a shame before, to creep to bed at ten and twelve for want of Company? No singing, nor no dancing, nor no drinking?— thou think'st not of these scandals— thou can'st snore, and sleep, and Chatter bawdy in thy Dreams,— and the next morning wake and go to breakfast, and nothing else— but his life shou'd be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: So it is, Sir— believe me, for I speak it to my knowledge, he's as mad as heart can wish; as debauch't a Fellow as any in the Suburbs.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Women, Sir, will talk, but you know we must bear with that sometimes.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Well, now I think on't, I will try the Boy once more, it may be he does but counterfeit, and then I'm happy— go, get you in, I'll keep you close enough, lest you break loose, and do more mischief to him— Within there. Exit Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Dee' call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Go presently, and seek the Boy, and bid him wait my pleasure in the morning— d'ee hear, Mark what house he's in, and what he does— and tell me truth.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I will not fail, Sir. Exit Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p:
If ye do, I'll hang ye. Come, Madam— I must desire you to stay here, till he comes, and
then wee'l settle all— there's your apartment, there you'l find all necessaries— Now if he prove but right, he has all yet; If not, this other way shall make an end on't.

lg.l: Youth may delight to boast of Act or Skill,
But the pleasure of an Old Man— is his Will.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: AT Valentine's house so merry?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: As a Lark, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: So frollicksome, do'st say?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I'm sure I heard it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ballads, and Fiddles too?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: No, but one Fiddle, but twenty noises.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Did he do Tricks?

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Ah, the rarest Tricks, Sir— here's my Fellow Launce, he can Inform ye all, he was among 'em, and as mad as any there; I stood up in a Corner.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Come, Sir— what can you say?— Is there any hope yet your Master may return?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Put your hand into your Purse— and give me an Angel, Then perhaps I may tell you more.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How, how? an Angel?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: An Angel, Sir— 'Faith not a Farthing under, such things, such roaring things— an Angel, Sir, quickly, come.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: There 'tis, damn'd Rogue, thou hast found my blind side.

sp.speaker: Launce.
