sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, that's all one— so— well now Sir, by the Virtue of 8: Languages, by the Faith of a Traveller and a Gentleman, Your Son is found agen, the Son— the Tom.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Is he the Old Tom?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: The Old Tom.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Proceed then.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Next to consider how he is the Old Tom.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ay, handle me that.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I wou'd you had seen it handled last night, as we handled it— Cap-a-pe, i'faith— oh the noise, the noise we made!

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Good, good, i'faith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: The house beset around— the Windowes Clatt'ring, and all the Chamber-Maids in such a hurrey, one with her Smock half off, Another in haste with a Hose upon her head.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: A Fellow railing there out of a Loupe-hole, and his Mouth stopt with dirt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, hah, ye Rogue. Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Another peeping out with his greasie Night-Cap on, and a Torch popt in's face to clear his eye-sight.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— Dog. Beats Launce, and is so— eager at laughing, he minds it not.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: The Gentleman himself, young Monsieur Thomas, environ'd with his furious Mermydons, the fiery Fidler and my self, Now singing, now beating at the Doore, there parlying— Courting at the Window, at the other, scaling.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: And all these several Noises to two Trenchers strung with a Clew of Brown Thred— which show'd rarely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— rarely well— rarely well. Beats him still.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Well, well— what d'ee mean, Sir— Your blowes are not well I'm sure, nor will my shoulders long, if you hold on at this rate.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: I'faith I beg thy pardon— I was so transported, I did not know what I did— there's money for thee to make thee amends— eat, and grow fat agen.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Nor here, Sir, gave we the Frollick over.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: What, more yet? why this is admirable.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: More, ay, and the best too, Sir— for at last we quit the Ladies house on composition— and to the silent Street turn'd all our furies. A sleeping Watchman here we stole the shooes from; there make a noise, at which he wakes and followes— then cryes out Theeves, and throwes his Bilboe at us— and Wades the Kennel in no footed stockings.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Oons— this is the rarest Boy, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Windowes and Signs we sent to Erebus— a cry of Butchers Currs we entertain'd last, and having let the Pigs loose in out-Parishes, made every Street look like a Bear-Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Instead of Bears, and Bulls, a Rogue, a Rogue.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Down— comes a Constable— and the Sow his Sister, most villainously tramples upon authority— there a whole Stand of Rug Gowns routed Manly, and the King's Peace put to flight— the Constable rallyes again— when, Sir, a Purblind Pigg— runs me his dirty Snout into his Lanthorn— out goes the light, and all turns to confusion.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: But, Sir, the best Jest was, a foolish Potter needs wou'd know the matter— opens his door, when, mark the Fate of Cuckolds, a Boare imbost takes sanctuary in his Shop, and Twenty Dogs rush after— We still cheering, down goes the Pots, and Pipkins— down the Pudding-Paus— the Cream-Bowles cry revenge here; There the Candlesticks; oh such a noise.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,—
If this be true, thou little Tyny Page,
This tale thou tell'st to me,
Then on thy Back will i presently hang.
A handsome new Livery.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How now, where's my Son?

sp.speaker: Servant,
sp.p: He's here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Now Sir— you shall hear all— and laugh abundantly, he has such a grace in telling it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Son Thomas— I am glad to see ye, and to hear of ye; You may be now my Son agen, if you please, and enjoy the blessings attending it— but come, because I feel a scruple in my Conscience, concerning your late carriage— and therefore like Father wou'd be satisfied; To clear all, Thomas, get you upon this Table.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: This Table, Sir? Lord, how you are misled!— what strange fancies are these? fitter for Fools and Mad-men.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: What, what?— come, come, I say, get you on this Table. and Instantly, I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you must be obey'd. Gets on the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: So— now Thomas, like a most compleat Gentleman come from Tripoly— relate your last Night's Frollicks, mince at nothing— but let me have it freely as 'twas acted— 'twill please me best.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Verily, Sir— though Age and Youth, and Youth and Age are different, different I mean divided 'twixt themselvs in point of reason; Nay, though our eyes are blinded, that is, though we cannot see.
I say— yet I say agen— or 'tis no matter whether I say it agen or no, That Reason, and Religion, shou'd Instruct Age to better courses than Blindness guides them to. Reason, and Religion are two worthy persons, and shou'd Instruct a wandring Mortal— Ah, Sir, remember— remember, I say, Take notice, place it in your Bosome— in your Heart, in your— I say, remember— that is, do not forget— but remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Hey day, he's preaching— you Rogue Launce, You lying Rascal.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Gad forgive me, will ye spoyl all agen, Sir?— What a Devil d'ee mean?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Away, Sirrah, and summon the rest of the Family hither, that I may edifie them all. Sir, you keep a Company of sawcy Fellowes, debauch'd, and daily Drunkards, that devour ye. Things, whose Souls tend to the Cellar onely.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Sirrah, give me my Money agen, or—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why Sir, let me never eat agen— or feel the Blessing of another new Livery, if he be not the very Devil in Debauchery, Sir: And what I have told you of him is all true; ask Robin here.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Nay Sir, the truth is, I did see my Young Master pick up two Whores, and put 'em into Pudding-Lane.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis strange these Rascals— but Sir, when Folly and Idleness take the upper hand of Reason, and permit when they meet and Inhabit the Heart, the Mind, the Soul, the Faculties, the— 'Tis a hard matter— 'tis, I say, a— matter of difficulty, of difficulty— a matter of moment— and all that, Sir, to reform or conform, or direct, or dispute, or disswade— or divine, or dispose, or—

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Or the Devil and all; come down, I say. Bless me! what stuffs here?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Sir, are ye mad? stark mad? did not I see ye beat a Constable last Night?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I touch authority, ye Rascal? I violate the Law?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: No, no, he had rather preach to him— Lancelot du Lake, Get ye upon adventures— cast your Coat, and make your Exit.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Pur l'amour de Dieu.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Pur me no purs— but get you out at that Doore there; Out ye Eight Languages.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: My blood upon your head Sir— Did not I tell you 'twou'd come to this? What shall I do to live now? if I beg, I shall be Whip't; and if I steal, I shall be hang'd. What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Heark ye, Sirrah; I'll provide for ye— go instantly and get the Fidler I order'd ye— let him be sure to be ready— and then go and
tell Vall and Iack I'll meet 'em within this half hour in the Rounds.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Now, now, Sir, dee hear him now?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, a word, and I'll cut your Throat— away.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Out of my doors, Sirrah. Exit Launce.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, ay, purge 'em all Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: I shall Sir— and you too presently. Go Sirrah, bid my Maids that stand without— come in— I will have one shall please me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis most fit Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Bring in the Money there— here Mr. Thomas.

div.stage: Enter Servant with two Bags. You are no more my Son, now good Gentleman be cover'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: This money I give you, because heretofore you have been thought my Son— and by my self too— and some things done like me; Ye are now another— here is two hundred pounds, a civil summe Sir, for a young Civil Man: Much Land and Money wou'd (I suppose) now onely prove temptations, to take you from your settled and sweet carriage.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How's this? but Sir, I hope—

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech ye, cover Sir; ye owe me no respect— I have nothing to do with ye; nor have you with my Estate Sir; Nor with this money neither, now I think on't— you can preach well Sir— Pray get a Tub— and deal about your Hums and Ha's with reverence; some of the Rabble perhaps may have farthings.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'S'death, I shall be finely bubbled if this hold— lose all my Fortune for a Frollick— I must wheel about agen, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: I have one thing more to say before we part Sir. Behold those females there, pray view 'em well: I want a right Heir to Inherit me, not my Estate alone, but my conditions, from which you are revolted— therefore dead— And I will break my back, but I will get one.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Will you chuse there, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p:
There, among those Damsels— in my own Tribe, I know their qualities— which cannot fail to please me, for their Beauties— a matter of three farthings makes all perfect. A little Beer, and Beef-broth— they are sound too— stand all abreast— Now Mr. Thomas, before I choose— You having liv'd long with me, and happily, sometimes with some of these too, which fault I never frown'd on— Pray
shew me (for fear we confound our Genealogies) which you have laid abroad: Speak your mind freely, Have you had Copulation with that Damsel?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I have. Sighs.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Say ye so? Pray how?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How, is not seemly here to say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Stand you aside then— What say you to'th second, Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: With her too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: With her too? ha, ha— the Rogue wins upon me strangely.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: So, so, he's coming agen. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Retire you two— speak forward Mr. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I will, and to the purpose— even with all Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How? with all? that's somewhat large, with all Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: All, surely Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: A sign thou art my own yet— in agen all, and to your several Functions— Mrs. I pray come hither— Exeunt Maids. Tom, here's a Lady— that I found my self, to the Whore. What think ye of her? she I'm sure's a stranger to ye.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: Mercy upon me, He here! nay then, I shall be murder'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: What, what's that? do'st know her Tom?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Know her? Why Sir, every Bulk about Town knowes her; I met her drunk i'th' Strand t'other Night, with twenty Boyes about her— I have thrown her into the Fleet Ditch— three several times for my share.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Go, get you gone too— and to your Bulk agen, my Marriage fit is over.

sp.speaker: Whore.
sp.p: And thank ye too, rather than stay where He is.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Well, but what say ye to Luce, the Merchant's Daughter? she was too young— I think, when you travell'd some twelve years old.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Her will was Fifteen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— 'Faith well answer'd to cut off long discourse, Thomas, for I have many yet to ask ye of, Where I may chuse, and nobly— hold up one finger;— where I may not, two— or more; What think ye of Valeria? whose husband lyes a dying now— why two and in that form. Holds up his 2 fingers.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Her husband is recovered, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: A Witty Moral— have at ye once more, Thomas— the Sisters of St. Albans— what all five?— ha, ha, that Boy, that's my own Boy— Holds up his hand.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Still hoping for your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Pshaw, there needs none— a pox on pardon— I am pleas'd with thy confession, Nor will I think of Marriage any longer; for o'my Conscience I shall be thy Cuckold— there, there's Twenty Guinneys for ye, Sir. Go, and be merry— I see some sparkles which may flame agen; and if they do, thou'rt mine yet— farewel Monsieur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: So— 'tis better thus, than t'other way however— but now to my Serenade— I have such a kind of a Mungril Love for this Woman— that I must, and will enjoy her, come what will on't— Oh Sirrah— well, hast got him?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I Sir, I have been here— a rare Rogue— hee'l Fiddle and make a noise, but the Devil a stop he knowes, or when he fiddles in Tune. Good Sir— do something now— some roaring thing, that we may live and eat agen— By my 8. Languages I have had but one poor mouldy Crust this two daies.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Pox on thee for an eating Rogue, Nothing but Famine frights thee— Come hither, Sirrah, what Ballads are you seen in best?— ha? let's hear.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Under your Masterships Correction, I can sing the Merry Ballad of Diverus and Lazarus. The Rose of England. In Creete when Dedimus first began. Ionas his Crying out against Coventry— and a merry Song, how Blind Toby and his Dog fell in Love with a Fair Lady, by seeing her play upon a Cymbal.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Very well. What else?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Maudlin the Merchant's Daughter. The Devil, and the Dainty Dames.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Rare still!

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: The Landing of the Spaniards at Bow; With the Bloody Battel at Mile-End.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Excellent! Well Sirrah, go, and put him to his Stand, and let my Friends be ready— I'll follow ye. Exeunt. I have heard, that sometimes Importunity gets more than Love: And 'Faith, I'll haunt her like a Ghost, but I'll have her. ha, ha, ha— It makes me laugh too, to think how I have Bobb'd my Father— had I been wild at first, he wou'd have been weary by this time; but now all's sure and settled.

lg.l: All you that would your good Old Fathers Cheat,
And e're his Death, do Covet his Estate;
To all his humours strict Compliance give,
For Age that doates once, has not long to live.

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Franck.
sp.p: Whatever your Nice humour, Madam, seems to declare now, I am sure you must needs sometimes be of a contrary temper— he is my Friend I acknowledge; and the least thing I can do in his absence, is to speak well of him.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Sir, that freedome is of necessity allow'd, and whatever his Merit is, your Generosity cou'd not do less— but my knowledg of him and his temper, is proof against all your assertions; I will allow him for a general Man, and good Company; but let me tell ye— such a one though he makes the best Servant— certainly makes the worst Husband in the World.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Ay, that is, Madam, according as you order him. If you give him liberty, 'tis true, Men are apt to follow the Dictates of their own humours— but when you have the Bridle in your hand, methinks 'tis easie stopping the course.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: That, Madam, does not so much depend on your own power, as on your husband's temper; for if he be rough and passionate, you have so much Judgment to know your bounds. But, if mild, and soft natur'd— Your Province is the larger. And there are two things which ruine such a man— Fondness and Folly; for a man that is too fond of his Wife, is as certain to be made a Cuckold by her— as that she wou'd if she cou'd do't— were he never so ugly, or Jealous.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: If good Phrases, and Reason might pass for Jests, I swear you are the merriest man I know.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: I shou'd be glad, Madam, I cou'd breed your Diversion any way; though to the rest of the World, 'tis my ambition they shou'd rellish me more in the Philosopher, than the Buffoon.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Fye, fye, a better word than that, Sir,— Call a Witty brisk Fellow, that breaks a Jest onely for the sake of good Company, or so, a Buffoon?— Fye, I swear 'twas ill said.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis a sign he has been sick lately.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: I do but think how you'd look, if Monsieur Thomas shou'd hear of this— you had best call Him Buffoon too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p:
No, He's the General of 'em,— and the onely Person that I know can be allow'd of in that nature; for he has Wit in his Buffoonry— and a graceful action, gives an excellence to his Jest.— If he tells a Lye,
he will be sure it shall be a pleasant one: And he never tells a bawdy story for its own sake, but the Companies, and the Mirth that followes after.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: What think ye of this, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Pish— Prithee what shou'd I think of it?— heark! what noise is this? Noise of singing and shouting within.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: But I have seen some dull Rogues Mangle a good Story so barbarously— how now? what's that?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Was ever the like known?— there is such a rout at your Window yonder— such shouting, such singing, and such a dismal noise—

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Noise? what noise? who is it?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: The mad Gentleman that us'd to ask for Madam Cellide, and twenty more, fidling, singing like Mad-men.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: 'Tis he— shall I never be at rest? who can endure this?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: He's as good as his word I see. Aside.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Heark ye, Cousin— now if you love me, let's put a trick upon him— I have a rare device in my head.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: I know this is against the grain, but come, I'll second ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: 'Tis a mad Rogue— but I know she loves him; I'll go up to my Closet-Window and see the sport. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Thomas, Hylas, Launce, Fidler, Valentine, and Linck-Boyes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Stand close now, and every one mind his business, Iack keep you that door there— and be sure none of her Servants enter, or go out— if any Woman pass, she is lawful Prize— Cut off all Convoyes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis not fit I am seen— I'll therefore stand at distance and observe ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ay, but heark ye Tom— who shall answer this?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why, I shall answer it, Sir;— You fearful Puppy I shall appear to th' Action.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Well, well, I have done— we may talk too, may we not?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: With any Woman freely.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: And sing too, ha?— for there's my Master-piece.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, Sir, by no means. I am the Man reserv'd for Aire— 'tis my talent, and the Devil's in't if my voice don't charm her; heark ye, You may Record a little— Whistle, or so— to shew you are good at something— but for main singing— let me alone; away, be careful.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: But there's another thing; we may be beaten.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith, so thou may'st— and well too— for thou deserv'st it richly— Why, what Bug-bears are in thy Brains? Beaten?— why who shou'd beat thee?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Why she may have men enough.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, art not thou man enough too?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I warrant thee— there's a low Window— I'll peep in and see what they are doing.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, let's hear some of your Art now— Nay, nay, No tuneing as ye love me— let thy Fiddle speak Welch, or any thing that's out of all tune— the Viler, still the better— like thy self— for I presume thy voice will make no Trees dance.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Nay, truly you shall have it even as homely.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: With all my heart, keep it to that Key still— I think they are all abed.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I think so too, Sir— I can hear no stirring any where, No light in any Window, 'tis a Night for the purpose, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, strike up a flourish— and Sirrah, do you sing the Serenading Song I taught ye t'other Night; Wee'l bear the Chorus.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Who's there? what noise is this?— what Rogue at these hours— dares disturb us thus?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh what is that to you ye Fool?
Oh what is that to you?
Pluck in your face— ye bawling Ass,
Or I will break your Nose.
With a hey downe, downe, downe, downa.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p:
Tom— here's rare sport— here's one of the Women washing her Legs— Ah Rogue!— 'Faith she has a fine plump Calf— ha, ha,— now she is come to her Knee—
oh— murder, murder— I'm kill'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Hah!— his face all bloody? Maid within shoots a squirt of blood in's face, and lets off a Pistol. Hold still Iack, let me see, Where's the Wound? this is no jesting matter.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I know not, I feel none— cannot you see it?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha, ha— I find it now— this was only a trick, a squirt of blood and a Pistol fir'd off— are they so frollicksome? have at 'em once more.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: 'Troth I'm glad I'm alive for all that— I'll go and get my face wash't, and come agen. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, now sing the English Ballad.

lg.l: There was a Noble Merchant
That lived in a Town,
He had an onely Daughter,
That was both fair and brown;
Sing hey trangdillo, dillo down.
A Noble Knight likewise,
On whom Fortune did frown,
He got her Maidenhead once in thrice,
Sing hey trangdillo down, down, derry down.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No stirring yet?— I believe the Devil has charm'd 'em asleep. Come, flourish agen, and the t'other Song—

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: The Twelfth of April on May-Day,
My House, and Goods were stolne away.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Hold, hold— she comes— Sirrah, give me the Address I gave you in writing t'other day.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, the Mice eat it in my Pocket one Night, but I have the Complement here that you took out of the Book of Common Places.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: That then, Sirrah, quickly— holdup the light— Madam. Were there no other light but your eyes— the World wou'd need no Sun— And— Conf— conserve me, Madam, if, like a Fly, I can forbear buzzing about that light— though I have burnt my Wings— ha? what think ye of that, Sirrah? To Launce.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Who wou'd forbear loving a Man that has such several wayes of Gallantry?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.l: Hush— you shall hear a Dialogue between us.
My Man Thomas did me promise
He wou'd Visit me this Night.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What? Musical?— nay, let me alone for answering that.
I am here Love, tell me dear Love,
How I may obtain thy sight.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.l: Come up to the Window my Love,
Come up to the Window my Dear;
Here's a Ladder of Rope,
That will help to guide thee up, Throwes down a Ladder of Ropes.
And thou sha't be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And 'Faith, I'll be with thee strait, she's very kind o'th' sudden, ha Sirrah?— go, all be gone, there's money.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ay Sir, so she is; you'l have good sport anon, ha?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Now Cousin— the Scuttle quickly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sir Eglamore that Valiant Knight, Sings going up.
Hey down, down a down;
So bruised was with grievous frights,
Hey down, down, downa down.
For he had been Cuffing so long with the Dragon,
That nothing could quench his thirst but a whole flaggon,
With a hey down, down, downa, &c.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How now? what a Devil— is this? Sabina throws down a Scuttle upon him. Sirrah, Launce?— what is the matter I'm Inchanted, I cannot stirr— bound hand and foot.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Nay, my Dear— why are you so slow? Prithee make haste.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A pox on ye— Launce— what a Devil is this?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Come down, Sir, come down— they have plai'd some trick or other with ye— ha, ha— I thought so. He comes down.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Fye, fye, so slow Sir; is this like a Mercurian?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith I'll be even w'you presently— 'S'death, a Basket! What Witches are these?— but I'll storm once more, and 'tis not Baskets, nor Chamber-pots, shall hinder me now; Sirrah, now sing.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Lucilla.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: I'm ready, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.l: The Duke, he was a Noble Man, as any in the Town,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Phoo, phoo— what's this? oh! He climbs up, and Lucilla with a Devil's Vizard frights him.

p.hi: But climbing to promotion, he suddenly fell down.
p.stage: She offers to Kiss him, and he falls down.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Death! this was another Trick upon me, I find by the Queans Mirth.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What hast thou done?— not thrown him down I hope.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Onely a little way, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: A little way?— Oh heaven I'm undone! she has broke his Neck.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha! is she so pitiful?— I may have a Trick then to recover all yet— oh my leg, my leg— I am spoil'd for ever; both my Legs. Sits down on the Stage, and holds his Legs.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Heark, heark, d'ee not hear him?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Shatter'd in twenty pieces, I'm undone! oh barbarous Woman! howl Sirrah, howl.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh, his back too! his back!— the bone is out of Joynt.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: D'ee hear ye Devil? run to the Surgeon quickly, fly: Or see my face no more. O horrid mischance! I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Take heed of Women, Friends, take heed of Women; They'l put ye out of Joint— they'l shake your Souls out. Oh, ha, my Legg! my Legg!

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Your head, your head too, Sir— for your Skull being crack't, Your Brains may happen to catch cold. Ha, ha, ha! The Light's taken away, I believe she's coming.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And cry out still— Men believe falsely that think Age makes 'em decrepid— No, 'tis Women, 'tis Women, oh—

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: She comes— she comes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, squeeze out a tear, or two— Now for a swouning fit— ah!— Lyes as in a swoon.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Where, where are ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: He's gone— he's gone. Master— sweet Master, here's Launce that calls— oh!— what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Oh I am miserable! Sir, Sir— Dear Sir— Oh cursed Accident! help! help to hold up his head!

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ah 'tis stiff, Madam— every part of him is stiff; rub him, rub him.

sp.speaker: Cellid,
sp.p:
Here, hold this Bottle of Amber to his Nose— Sir, Dear Sir, Open your eyes, and see my sorrow for ye; 'tis I that speak Sir.
For Heavens sake open your Eyes— I am here. Holds him in her Arms.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay— and— I am here too— and well— thank my Activity; Your Bottle of Amber will be unnecessary, And if thou scap'st me now— Catches hold of her.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What, catch't agen! oh this subtle Devil!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: However, I am bound in Conscience to thank you for your kindness— and since 'tis onely Trick for Trick, Madam, we have the more reason to be friends— I must needs own my self oblig'd t'ee; for the Devil take me if I have been kiss'd so heartily this great while.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— 'tis strange your Legs shou'd be cur'd already Sir; But, Madam— he is such a Wagg— ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Well— I have no other way, but seeming to comply.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come 'faith be kind now— I have a convenient Lodging here hard by— and one reconciling here now, will be worth Ages.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Fye! What baseness is this?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, that's all one— If I leave my self to a doubt agen— May I be Jilted as I have been— Come Sirrah, and help—

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Hold Sir— well, now I see you love me; and believe Sir, this Impatiency has taken me far more than all your Addresses: Violence, will now be unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ah, no Tricks, Madam— to be plain with ye, if you will marry me— so— if not, I am resolv'd to enjoy ye before I part, and then marry who you please.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Nay, that shall not need, I swear, if you have a Priest ready— I have try'd thee long enough; and though y'are a little Wild— I know you can love truly— ah my Dear Sweet! Embraces.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why Ay. this is like something now,— Sirrah, have I not wrought her rarely?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ay, ay, but to her, to her Sir, don't let her cool.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come my Dear, shall we go in here, or to my Lodging?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Your Lodging, no indeed— I'll have the confirmation made here, follow me; but hold, 'tis convenient the Candle be out, for if my Cousin sees me, she'll so laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Faith, well consider'd; besides, light in such a case is a little unnecessary— Sirrah, turn the Lanthorne— so.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: And will you always love me?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: This kiss shall confirm it.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What ye Clown— with your Hat on? and to your Mistress too? You cou'd do no more if I were your Wife. Throwes his Hat away, and whilest he gropes to find it, falls. She runs in; and locks the Door. So, I am once more Conqueress, Now let him catch me if he can.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Who the Devil wou'd ha' thought, you should expect Ceremony in the dark?— Where, where is it Sirrah?— Oh here, Come, now let's go— I'm impatient till— S'death what's that? Runs and stumbles over Launce.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ha! She's gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How! gone!

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: I have only leisure now to bid you good night Sir, and wish your leg well cur'd— to morrow perhaps, you may hear more. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Pox fetch thee— that's but the preamble. Still thus bubbled?— Sirrah help me to curse her. May she fall in love with an old man that's bed-rid, Afterwards, consider of it, despair, and then poyson her self with her own Mercury.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: May she be proud to that degree to scorn all her Sex, Then get the small Pox, and look like a Witch, that all her Sex may scorn her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well sed; or may—.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: May she get a great Belly by imagination— and when she hopes to see the precious Off-spring— may it prove Fire and Brimstone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well sed agen— Gad thou hast a pretty gift at it— but come, now let's be gone— and plot how to plague her to morrow, for if I leave her thus, may I lose all my Fame and turn Civilian.

lg.l: Men raile at Whores for Luxury and cost,
But believe me, all you that Iudgment boast,
'Tis your damn'd honest Women Iilt ye most.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCNE I.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: NOble Sir Peregreene, this unexpected favour of honouring my house with your Company is so far above my hopes— that I want words to express my sentiments of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p:
Sir, your complements put me in mind of the Debt of
gratitude I owe ye— for my Daughters kind Entertainment:— I fear I have too much trespass'd upon your patience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Fye Sir Peregreene, I thought you had known me better than to Imagine so poorly of me— your Daughter I assure ye has been a grace to my Family.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Any one Sir that has the good fortune to be in her Company will rather think it a blessing, then a trouble, especially if he be of my opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Sir I thank ye, and 'twas a business of Moment that brought me hither; for yesterday in the afternoon I had a Letter from Sir Wilding Frollick— proposing a Marriage between his Son and my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, with Monsieur Thomas?

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: The same— I am so vext I forgot to bring it with me, 'twou'd have made you laugh heartily— for in my life I never saw so extravagant a style;— now Cousin my business in Town is, to put a stop to this Match, for I hear he comes often to her, and against her Will too,— does he so Cousin?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sometimes Sir— by way of visit, or so— but not against her consent, that ever I heard of, and you know Sir, 'twou'd not be civil in me to deny her visitants.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Cousin, you say well— but we Fathers perhaps have better eyes to pry into these matters— then your Youngsters have; she's a good Girl Sir, and I think a Fathers Indulgence shou'd be carefully imploy'd in bestowing a good Girl upon a good Man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Oh all the reason in the World Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Why very well— then to be plain, his fame is none of the cleerest— for in troth we hear in the Country, he is ten times more mad, and debauch'd since he came from Paris, then he was before— they say, he never says his Prayers.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not publiquely I think Sir— but he may be the better for that.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p:
Oh no— and between you and I, I don't relish him— not like him I mean, and my Judgment▪ and good liking have gone hand in hand these 50 years— and think I am not crazy now Sir; there is an Imposition laid upon us Fathers— by the Law of Nature— to be Elaborate, and Zealous in our care for our Children; and though I profess t'ee Cousin, I entertaine no ill sentiments as to matter of his estate, I do as to the matter of his manners; mark me, I say his manners, for, believe me, however corrupt affections— put a false gloss upon a Fathers charge, yet it is certainly requir'd of him to be very circumspect
in his consideration, when it tends to the disposal of his Children;— but come, pray let me see her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, Im afraid she's hardly stirring yet— but she'll soon be ready— I'll wait on ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Cousin, your very Servant. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: This Knight is as much affected with his formal Oratory as a Judge at the Sessions House, and if his humour hold, I fear may lose▪ his Mistress in spight of all his Intrigues.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.p: how do'st thou?

sp.speaker: Hylas
sp.p: 'Faith, better to see thee so well agen Franck, but prithee hast thou seen Tom today?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: No— what mad Rogues you were last night to make such a noise.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Did'st thou hear us? we were very frollicksome, that's the truth on't— for my part I thought he was mad.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Ay, but here's one come to Town, that will spoil his mad frollicks (her Father, Iack) he came early this Morning— and with intent to stop all proceedings.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Her Father! S'death what luck's this— where is he?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Gone in with Val. to see her— come, go with me, I'll help thee to the sight of him.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: With all my heart, it may be I may do him a kindness by it— Pox on him, has he smelt the business out already? Exit.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Thomas, Lucilla, and Launce.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, stay you there and watch— Exit Launce. Her Father in Town say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Yes Sir, he came this morning; and since your bounty Sir has made me your Creature— I cannot but inform you that he is much incens'd against you— and if he sees you— he may perhaps fly into more Passion.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll be gone then. Damn'd Rogue, that he did not give me warning!

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Sir, There's no going out there, if you do you'l meet him, You must have a little patience— come hither— here's a standing Press— that my Master uses to hang Cloathes in, Get in here and you are safe, I'm sure they will not stay long.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Pox, mew'd like a Cat in a Cupboard— what damn'd luck's this! Gets into the Press.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peregreene, Valentine, Franck, Hylas, Cellide, and Sabina.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Cousin, it has been longer my study— therefore I shou'd know more of Men and Manners than you— Mum, mum— I say to you once more she shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry he has the ill fortune to be no better known to ye; but 'tis fit your Judgment shou'd have precedency, especially, as to this affair.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— there in that Press say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I warrant in an Ague by this time.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Hush, not a word on't— I'll plague him for his last nights work; Sir I hope you know my Obedience is so settled, to believe my Youth shall never make me throw my self away upon a Man— you dislike— and one that I confess is the General of all mischief— and the lewdest, and most debauch'd person in Town.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: So— she has hit me to a hair— Peeping out.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Her mind is very suddenly alter'd, or else this must be Cunning.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Child, remember my Caution, my blessing shall follow; and observe this as a Maxime, (which though not in Epithetus, yet is in Aratine— or some such merry Book, which in troth I have forgot) That the Marriage Bed is never happy, except the Father eats part of the Posset— 'tis somewhat familiar, but the sence is strong.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Very strong Sir, and in my Judgment extends to many things.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: It does so. Do ye know this Man we speak of Sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Some small acquaintance, Sir— his Person, not his humour.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Your name good Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Hylas— at your Service— Sir Robert Hylas Son of Essex.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Indeed? let me embrace ye— your Father was my Intimate and good Friend; are you Sir Robert Hylas Son, say ye? By my faith, I am glad to see you. Your Father was the best Man of Land we had in Essex, when I knew him.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I think he had enough to keep him warm Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: And you I think are his Heir— let me embrace ye once more— 'faith, I shou'd think my Daughter better bestow'd, if— but I'll not begin.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Hum!— his Daughter— Sir I have 15 hundred or so; this wou'd be rare— and she's a delicate Girle— Well— sit fast Monsieur Thomas— I never refuse blessings, I.

sp.speaker: Sir. Per.
sp.p: A man of no Principles; no, I will not have you think of him.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: I will not Sir— but as of a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: A Whirligigg.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: A Monster— that on my Conscience— has more Wenches— that take pay of him, than the Grand Signior has.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: That's a lye, for I never paid a Whore in my life. Peeps out.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What think ye Sir?— I'm sure you cannot but be more my Friend than his— Pray speak.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: 'Faith she seems willing too— well, I begin to be damnably in Love— this must be the Twentieth, I find it.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Will you be so unkind to be silent, Sir?— I'm sure this Aside. galls him. Is he not the basest fellow in Town?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: In Town? nay in Christendome— I think he's the greatest Corrupter of Youth, and Debaucher of Women in the whole World.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Rare Rogue!

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: I marry him? what, a Fellow that makes it his business to be wicked?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: That never considers on his latter end, but Wenches on to perpetuity.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ay, and that never is out of a course of Physick, but to gain time to get in agen.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Right, Madam— that never will be found— nor I think hardly ever was.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Very well, the Rascall's witty now he thinks me absent, But I shall make you smart for this my damn'd Friend, I shall.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is this done like a Friend, Iack?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: No 'faith; but 'tis like a man in Love, and that hopes to bubble his Friend tho.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Be not too confident of your success— there will be some danger in't; for you know he dares fight.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Ay, but he is absent now— why when I see him Man, I'll forswear all agen.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: The Rogue has a tender Conscience however. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Mr. Hylas— introth I like your humour, and Company so well, That I desire to have you acquainted with my Daughter; she's a good Girle Sir— Pray be familiar with her.

sp.speaker: Cellide,
sp.p: Prithee, look on this Gentleman— 'faith he pleases me well.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot doubt but in a little time his Merit, and Witty conversation— will give me the content you receive in him— Now he frets rarely. Aside.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Still more strange!— sure 'tis not possible she can be thus flexible.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Prithee go, and address— I believe she has a mind to thee.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Sir— 'tis a happiness too great; 'S'death, this is the Civill'st Old Fellow— I ever met with— Madam, be pleas'd to enroll me among your Vassals.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: My Father's pleasure prefers ye Sir— you may command me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Very fine— Faith I have been debauch'd to fine purpose if this last;— but the worst is, that this dull Rogue shou'd bubble me— 'S'death I shan'not have patience.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: The Devil take me Val. if I can help this, 'tis a Fortune thrown upon me— and you know if it were your own case—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'll not be concern'd in't Sir— if you'l venture a Beating, You may do what you please.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a suspitious Fellow, has been prying up and down the house for above this hour; I believe h'has stole something.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Jernie, stole something!— I'll be Judg'd by all dis Company, who look most like a the Thief, you or I.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: O Rascal, are you here? examine him Sir, here's one Plot or other contriving.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Sir— this is his Rascal, his Procurer— one that he employes to set his Whores for him.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Oh— is he so— I thought there was more in't than ordinary, Bring him before me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirrah, bear up boldly, and fear nothing, I'll stand thy Friend.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Well, well— and what have you to say to me you Son of a— I say Sir— what have you to say to me?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I say, you are his Pimp, Sir— and by the leave of this Company shall be whipp'd, and toss'd in a Blanket.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ah no!— a Jirk or so, if you please— but no Blanket, That is a little too ungentile— Jernie, when did you ever see a Frenchman toss'd in a Blanket?— Where the Devil is my Master gone now?

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Stand by, Let me examine him; Friend, it agrees not with the reserv'dness, and solidity of your Countenance, to be so far forgetful of your self, as to embroile, Or rather Incumber your Wit, about this Criminal Affair.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Come, be genuine with me— here's a Protector's half Crown for thee— two shillings five pence sterling— and let it be a Key to unlock thy heart— Do'st thou come upon any Sinister Design?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Sir, upon my faith— I stood there only to watch, that was all.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: To watch us— oh—

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Plac'd as a Spy Sir— come deal freely, and I'll entertain thee; What new Pranck is your Master about?

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Tell that, I've another Protector for thee.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Why then Sir, to say the truth, my Master is a plaguy— Debauch't Fellow— he never goes to Church— he sayes there's no good Company there; and my business here was to give him warning— if any came to disturb him when he was with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: 'Tis plain now he wou'd have ravish't her— go fetch me a Cudgel, I'le make you an Example.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, what d'ee mean? Opens the Door of the Press, and Tho, is discover'd.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: There's for your Commendations, Dogg.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How!— in the Press?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis evident— he came to rob the house.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nothing but confidence can bring me off, therefore have at 'em— well, Gentlemen— have you look't your fill?— pray observe me once agen; 'tis I, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: How!— has he heard all then?— what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: This is a little uncivil, by your favour, to hide your self in my house without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Hold Cousin— let me speak— Sir— to lay the Law t'ee, wou'd perhaps be insignificant, you not understanding it; Reason too is lost upon ye, because you are a Mad-man— Yet, though these two fail— anger— has its full power; Nor shall my Daughter want a Champion— whil'st she has a Father— You conceive me Sir— Prepare your self.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Take him at his word— I'll be thy Second.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What, in a Game at Tennis?— but now I think on't, thou art too dull for that too— for thy Wit and Courage have been much of a stamp ever since I knew thee. Hush, not a word more— I'll talk with you anon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: I shall be swing'd— I see there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Now for my faculty, I'm resolv'd this Jilt shall not carry it off so— Sir, since I see you are a Man of Honour, and Jealous, and mindful of Injuries, and for some reason best known to my self, being now resolv'd that all shall out— know, 'twas by your Daughters contrivance— that I was shut up here.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: My Daughters?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Very well, he's fetching it off with a lye, but that shan't do;— heark'ee, Sir, what d'ee mean by that?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Nay, Madam— what did you mean by it. Sir, for me to say she is honest

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Is a lye?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Oh Heavens!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Wou'd not be, I confess, so like a Gentleman, but that she is given to subtlety, and wantonness— give me leave to confirm it; For to be faithful with you, this was the day appointed for a certain business 'twixt she and I. You understand me, to which purpose I was shut up there— 'faith I must needs say much against my own good humour and Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Umph— I begin to discern it now, this was a Plot— Huswife— see my face no more.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Oh horrid Impudence! Pray hear me speak, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, this must not pass, upon this Lady without better grounds.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir, you shall have what ground you please, and Where. What Madam, I warrant you are amaz'd at this?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: I do confess I am.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Heark ye, Sir— d'ee hear that?— she confesses it— after this— sure there's nothing remains to prove the truth of my Story: Madam, I am heartily sorry, it shou'd be my ill fortune to relate this— but you must pardon me— I do it for the discharge of my Conscience, and so your most devoted— heark ye, shall I lye with ye to night?— Be kind— I'll recover all yet— I'll stay half an hour for your answer at the next Tavern; consider on't— Gentlemen your Servant— and You Sir— To Hylas. A part of whose Nose I desire to be oblig'd with as a remedy against my Cold— my kind good natur'd civil. Son of a Whore— Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: Pox on him— what a plaguy twitch he gave me.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: I hope he has forgot me, but I must follow him, and if he will be contented with a Limb— I'm happy. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: My rage has almost suffocated me— but I'll instantly go and cut off the Intail of my Estate, and leave her as despicable as she has left her honour.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Sir, let reason mitigate your passion, this may be all false.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: May be, upon my life it is— Pray Sir, let me speak a word with ye in private. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Infamous Creature!

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p:
Was ever such an Impudent lye carried so prosperously? By Heaven I was so confounded, I had no power to speak a word: I must have this recover'd, and suddenly, I'm undone else.—
He told me when he went— he wou'd stay for my answer at the next Tavern— go you instantly, and tell him I have consider'd, and desire to speak with him privately in my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I'll warrant I'll bring him back.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: I have one Trick more in my head, that if it prospers, is certain to recover all yet; for the Love I had for him is so turn'd in a desire of Revenge— that I cannot rest till it be done. Enter Mrs. Dorothy. How, his Sister? she must know nothing.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: What, alwayes in Contemplation? shall I never find thee otherwise?— Why, thou hast quite deserted thy merry humour; Prithee Cellide, what ayl'st thou?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Now I think on't, her Company may be advantagious to me, If made use of rightly— Come— thou shalt know all, and I must therefore confess the subject of my thoughts was thy mad Brother.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: What, are ye reconcil'd? I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: In a fair way to't— hee'l be here within this hour, to confirm the bargain— and if I cou'd, I wou'd have his Father be by, and over-hear it.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: I'm sure hee'l come willingly, for he's very much pleas'd with the Match, tho' our Father be against it.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Do, and I'll Order my Woman to place him conveniently.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, we shall have rare sport. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Rare sport indeed— as I will order it— for his Father, and Sister to be by— when I put the Trick upon, will be a rare venture— heark, I think he's coming, I'll to my Chamber, and prepare for him.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: What, Sir, d'ee think I tell ye a lye?— I hope you see more grace in my Physiognomy— than to believe that.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay gad, if Deformity be a grace in a Woman— thou I confess hast a considerable share on't.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Come, good Sir, spare your Expressions till ye come to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Away then— Sirrah, for the last business I forgive ye. But if you fail in your charge agen.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p:
No Sir, Ill be doubly careful now— I understand my Trade.
What a Devil, I have not been a Pimp so long for nothing.

div.head: SCENE II. A Chamber.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: You shall find me bountiful— but be sure to do as I bid ye, and be all ready when I give the Sign, then leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Madam, we will not fail.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Away then, and watch your time.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Madam, he's come.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: So. Is he alone?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: No Madam, his Man is with him.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Then 'tis as I wou'd have it; for I am resolv'd that Rascall shall partake in my revenge— be sure you are ready with a Rope when I give the word.

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: But first, go to my Father, and tell him my Design to prove my Innocence— and when his Father comes, place both the Old Men in that Window there, where they may see all; Away, I hear him coming. Exit Lucilla.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— have you consider'd then, Madam? Will you allow me a Man of Wit now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Nay, I confess I deserve you shou'd laugh at me for sending to ye— but I swear I was not able to let you go, till you had ask't my pardon for the affront you put upon me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: An affront? not in the least 'faith— a little harmless rallery, that was all— why thou art not such a Fool to think my Father believ'd me, Do'st? No, no, he knew I was in Jest.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Now is he going about another Swinger— well, I believe I have the lying'st Son of a Whore to my Master that ever was born-fifty an hour is nothing to him.—

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: A Jest?— what your swearing that I shut ye into the Press with Intent to have you lye with me? a Jest?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Nothing else upon my Faith.— Come, let all be forgot; and since we have given proof of one another's Wit— let us now
come to the tryal of our Persons— Come my Dear— your promise— Pox, must Enter Lucilla. This Creature molest us now?— Prithee send the Bawd of an errand.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Promise, or not Sir— you are like to stay till we are married, I'll assure ye— Well, are they come? and have you plac'd 'em as I order'd ye?

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, there in that Window— look up, you may see 'em.

div.stage: Sir Wilding and Sir Peregreene above in a disguise.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— the Rogue has her there.— Now I shall see if he behaves himself like a Cock of Four, or no.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: And I shall see how she behaves her self— but Mum—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, prithee leave whispering; These Young Bawds are never good for any thing but mischief.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: She shall be gone immediately— but first for the safety of my Honour, confess before her— that what you sed in the Hall before my Father, was a lye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, I confess it was— now begone Mistris, be gone I say; and do you, Sirrah, hide your self below till I come, and be sure you are not seen.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Hold, I must have a word with him first— be gone, and get the Rope ready. To Lucilla.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: With Him?— Pox, prithee lose none of thy breath with Him, let Him go.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: 'Tis for your safety, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: So, now the Old Woman's gone— now Cock of Four.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Friend, there is a weighty business impos'd upon you, for your Master's good; for Sir Ferdinand had never pull'd him by the Ears— if Pomgranats had been in season. Now you being a Schollar, and Homer you know loving Paremains— sent all the Lobsters in the Levant to Massinello the Fisher-man— You understand me?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Yes, yes— gads noons not a word— not I— You say, Madam, that I being a Scholar, proceed— pray.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p:
You, I say, having read Aristotle— and knowing Mice to be very destructive to the Common-Wealth, cannot but consider what your Master may suffer; for there is as much difference in Perrukes, as in Bucklers, and the Cardinal Bobinello loosing one of his Teeth with a Skirmish 'twixt him, and the Pigmies— Your Master's
Interest will be left in the hand of Sir Ieoffry, or the Heere Hander van Dander Scopen; D'ee conceive me?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I think I do. Madam, I speak 8. Languages; I assure ye therefore, I think I understand ye.

div.stage: Enter Lucilla above with a Rope.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, come, Madam— what business can she have with this dull Rogue?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Oh she is ready I see— Now Sir, I come to ye.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Nay Sir, no struggling, Stamps, and they all come in, and disarm and bind him. our Power shall master ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Damn'd, Cowardly Dogs— and damn'd dull Rogue as I was to venture my self here, knowing her so well.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What, you are running away, Sirrah, are ye? come, the Rope, the Rope quickly. Lucilla throwes a Rope down, and they tye it about Launce his Neck.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: O mercy, mercy! Why you will not be guilty of such barbarity, will you? to hang up 8 Languages?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How, how, Tom? beset, and bound— then 'tis time to discover my self— Courage, Tom— Courage, I am here— I'm here.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Ay, and I am here too, Sir— nay, sit still— for here's no getting out.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: How Sir Peregreene— 'S'bud, this was a Plot, Discovers himself. I find it now.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: So, this Service has oblig'd me— but now begone all, and leave him to me. Exeunt Servants.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: My Father here too! Pox, this is worst of all— Oh I cou'd curse now! well, he that loves a Woman, loves his Torment— and he that Courts her—

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, have you consider'd yet, Sir?— will ye allow me a Woman of Wit now? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— a Rare Girle I profess.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; well, I was a damn'd Insipid Rogue, that's the truth on't— but Madam, little did I think you cou'd have been thus ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.p: Ungrateful! why thou shallow inconsiderate unthinking fool, Cou'dst thou Imagine I cou'd sleep— and leave thy last affront unpunish't? No, all my Faculties were turn'd to Thought & Revenge. Nor get ye your Liberty, till I have it throughly.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: But what harm did I do, Madam? You know I took your part— oh—

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: What, Sirrah, are you prating? I'll stop your noise.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, I shall get loose agen— and then if you persist in this usage, I shall then be implacable— You know, Madam, I have Wit..

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: What, d'ee threaten me?— I know you have Wit; Where, where is it? for my part, I am blind to it; but I can give ye some, Sir— thus— and thus— Strikes him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Who ' Pox— Prithee forbear— 'S'death, this is barbarous.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: O, 'tis a blessing you want, Sir— and pray let me infuse it into ye— You cheated me, I remember, with your broken Legg, last Night Sir, and roar'd, and howl'd, and laugh't and fool'd me Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Oh Devil, this is past sufferance.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Told a swinging lye this morning to prove me a Whore, Sir, to my Father; for which there is a swinging cuff, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Umph— nay enough, enough— come— I'll reform.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: And so will I too— I'll never Pimp for him, no— oh—

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Still prating, Rascal?

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Oh that plaguy Quean— that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: You must have patience, Sir— a sweet Girle I profess.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: What, is the Monsieur catch't?— the plotting Monsieur? Ha, ha, ha— this is strange I swear Sir— where was all your Wit?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Dam her, Is she come too?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Ay, where indeed— ah Cousin, he's so cruel to me, here have I lain languishing this hour, Throwes her self on a Chair. and not so much as a kind word from him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ah Devil!

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— what, and his Spaniel here too? What, Sirrah, Cannot your 8 Languages free ye from that Rope?

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ah, wou'd they cou'd.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Now I think on't— I shou'd bestow a little Wit on you, Sirrah— my Lying— Pimping— Ugly Impudent Varlet— There's for ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oh! wou'd my Master had been hang'd seven years ago, rather than I had come to this— oh—

sp.speaker: Lucill.
sp.p: Again Rogue, agen; ah 'tis gone. Goes to pull him, and; lets fall the Rope.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Oones I am deliver'd by Miracle; Look up, Sir, look up— I am free— Nay, 'faith Madam, I beg your pardon, I must be Porter now. Runs, and stands in the Door.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How? free? nay then, Fate is mine agen, Sirrah, lock the Door, and take out the Key.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: 'Tis done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come then, unbind me quickly.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Cur'st Accident— Catch't agen?— help, help.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, Faith— I'll help ye presently, Your humble Servant, and Devoted Lover, Madam, is making what haste he can.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: How! at Liberty?— Nay then 'tis time to help indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: By Bacchus, Sir, but you shall not— now 'tis my turn to be Porter; Now Son Thomas— now Cock of Four— now Rogue, now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, for this piece of Service— there's a Lady for ye; Sabina. Take her, be thankful, and multiply.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: Ha, ha— with all my heart 'faith— come Madam, 'gad I have not had a touch a great while.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— ha, ha, ha, what think ye now, Madam? Wheres your Wit now?— Did I not tell you what a stubborn denyal must come to? 'gad if thou scap'st me now— let me be recorded an Ass, and my Story put into a Ballad. Goes to undress her.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Nay, do not dishonour me good Sir; if you love me— I'm sure you will not— I confess I have wrong'd ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Dam Confessions, Madam— do that when the business is done, and then I'll confess with ye.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: And I must confess too.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Kind, Dear Sweet Sir, help, help!

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Well sed Tom, Well sed Tom, to her agen Son Thomas, to her agen Boy— ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Rascal, Villain, Debauch'd Villain, thou wilt not ravish her, wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, upon my Faith not I; I▪ ll onely lye with her, that's all.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not lye with her before my face?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Yes but I will tho'— and before my own Father's face too; But for your sake, Sir, I ll use her as kindly as I can.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: 'Gads noones, this is sport. Knock at the Door.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Savage, Barb'rous Villain— oh Heaven! what sin have I committed, to undergo this punishment? help, help; help—

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Rather kill me Sir, than do it. Help, help. Knock within.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Apox on 'em— they have taken the Alarm— I see— 'gad I must dispatch— I find I shall be hinder'd else. Takes her in his Arms, and carries her to the Closet.

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Help, help,— I'm undone else— help, help.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'S'death! What Barbarity is this?— what were you going to do with the Lady, Sir? ha?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Why, I was going to teach her a new Dance, Val.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay, I believe 'twas a Dance indeed.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peregreene, Sir Wilding, Franck, Hylas.

sp.speaker: Sir Per,
sp.p: Kill him, kill him— let him be murder'd— let me come to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir— this must not be in my house.

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: I ll lay the Statute of Ravishment against him, I'll have him hang'd, I'll take the Law on him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: You take a Coxcomb, will you?— Tom, give me thy hand, Fifteen hundred a year is thy own for this dayes work; And now talk of the Law, Sir, if you dare— Tom and I will swinge ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Now, Madam, cou'd not you have sav'd all this, and been willing?

sp.speaker: Cellid.
sp.p: Impudent Man! cou'd no entreaty prevail with ye? Well, from this instant I'll shun thee as I wou'd the Plague; and if I do speak of thee, it shall be with Scorn, and Derision— to curse thy ill Nature— and Ingratitude— to which purpose I this Moment banish all sparks of Love— and do here solemnly vow— Never to see thee more.

sp.speaker: Sabin.
sp.p: Nor I, unless it be to revenge this baseness. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Pox on't, this comes of Interruption, if they had but stay'd a little longer, that I might have had earnest of her, all had been sure;— but one Weeks humble Address shall make all well agen, shall it not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Per.
sp.p: No Sir, Not believe I'll put up this affront so tamely: You shall hear from me, assure your self. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Ah, let him go, Tom— the Old Fool frets— ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Launce.
sp.p: A Pox on't, I have had the greatest Loss— for methought my Nymph began to be willing.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Thou wilt?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I warrant ye, Sir, And now to you my Friends— first Val. I beg thy pardon for offering this in thy house— Prithee forget all— and from this Minute— assure thy self— I am thy Friend indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well Sir— having some Interest in the rest of your Frollicks, I have the more reason to bear with this— especially since 'twas onely a Design— But had you gone through with your Dance— You and I shou'd have made but a kind of a scurvy Salutation.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: For thy sake onely, I am glad it hapned otherwise— Dear Franck, give me thy hand too.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: With all my heart— and believe I share a great deal of content in seeing you two friends; for when I came in first— I guest it wou'd be otherwise—

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I believe thou did'st.— What Iack art thou behind? here come forth, and give me thy hand too— Come, all is forgot; Thou art a damn'd Inconstant Rogue, I believe thou wilt confess it: but let that pass. We have all our failings.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.p: We have so— but this Kindness in thee has so oblig'd me— that I am resolv'd to desert my Roaring Humour, and turn all into Friendship for thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Wild.
sp.p: Well sed Cock of Four— 'gad I like it well— Come Gentlemen— Pray let me Invite ye to my house— I'll provide a Collation, and we'l be heartily merry.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Come, you shall go 'faith— for I am resolv'd to give my farewel to Intrigues, with a free and merry heart; and 'tis fit that you that are my Friends, shou'd be now my Witnesses, as you shall be when I go through the t'other Gate, Marriage. And tho' this kind of life is least troublesome; t'other is certainly most safe: especially, if a Man can change his Temper, else 'tis a Plague to him. For Marriage to a Debauchee, is a second Purgatory; It gives him onely a Prospect of Joy, or Torment, without knowing which he shall arrive to. But I hope I know my self better, than to venture without great Consideration to such Uncertainties.

lg.l: Loose Love like a thin Garment serves us ill,
And though wee'r pleas'd with it, we shiver still;
But I'm confirm'd, let th' Age be what it will,
What ever Nature in a Miss design'd,
Wives only are the Blessing of Mankind.

div.head: EPILOGUE, By Mr. Mohun.
div.l: THat I have been a Mad Old Fool to Night,
I need not tell you; but to set all right,
The Poet now makes me a Parasite.
Sends me to flatter ye, and beg Excuse,
For the Insipid Errors of his Muse:
He bids me say, the less to show his Guilt,
On the Foundation Fletcher laid, he built;
New drest his Modish Spark fit to be shown,
And made him more Debauch'd, t' oblige the Town.
Drink, Rant and Sing, he now takes pains to be
A perfect and accomplish'd Debauchee.
But Criticks, you that never yet were known
To think there could be Sence above your own;
You that do surfet on the Spoyles of Witt,
And still have less to shew, the more you get.
Like barren Ground that swallowes up the Rain,
Yet is by th' Industrious Hand Manur'd in vain,
Will in your Censures your Ill Natures show,
And with your Weeds choak up the Grain we sowe.
I know you'l cry, Confound this tedious Stuff,
He has not made the Spark half mad enough;
He should have been all Air, and th' Mode pursue,
That is, keep Miss, kick Wise, and Run Men through:
Ashore you give good proofs of this each day;
Pray Heav'n you hold and prove as mad at Sea.
But that I think there's none can doubt or fear;
No,— Witt's a greater Plague to you than Warr.
Witt that is now us'd like a Common slave,
Both by those have none, as well as those that have.
Therefore against such to procure defence,
Not doubting th' Aid of all the Men of Sence,
The Poet now the Ladies help do's Crave,
That with a frown or smile can damn or save.
And as the Mighty God of Witt shines clear,
And shines upon his Fav'rites once a Year;
From them that Sacred Influence let him find,
That he may say he Once found Beauty kind.
